Arianrhod walked across the endless sea, her bare feet scarcely touching the surface of the green waters. Her hair, her gown, and her cheeks shone with windswept beads of moonlight.

And then she was a bird, drifting on white wings beneath the starry sky. Then a silver wheel, mixing water with darkness as it revolved. At last, a woman again, with flame-colored hair and a jewel-green gown to match her eyes.

The goddess reached the black sands and halted on the beach. She raised a hand in greeting.

“Good morning, cousin!”

Arawn sat hunched in his throne by the water’s edge, leaned over the mess of yellowed papers, spilled ink, broken quills, and scattered bones atop his desk.

“Morning?” he grumbled. “You come to Annwn speaking of morning? It is always midnight here, Arianrhod. Surely it has not been so long since your last visit to the lands of Death that you have forgotten that.”

Arianrhod laughed—a splash of silver in that dark place. “Am I not a goddess of dawn? Wherever my feet do tread, there is morning.”

“Goddess of dawn?” he sneered, setting down his quill and steepling his fingers on the desktop. “I thought it was the moon and stars, the womb, rebirth. And what else was it the old priestesses credited you for? Ah yes: the flow of time and fate. Which is it, cousin?”

“Like you, I have many talents,” said Arianrhod.

“You are nothing like me.”

“We are both…romantics,” she mused, stepping closer to her cousin’s throne. “In our own ways, of course. I find beauty in the morning fog, in the cry of a babe, in the first kiss and the last kiss. And you? You seek it in other forms—in turmoil, war, and chaos.”

She peered over Arawn’s bent head, past the black beach to the heart of Annwn. A forest of souls loomed in the distance like the silhouettes of broken dolls, limbs limp, shadows swaying in a breeze that was not there.

“Chaos.” Arawn whispered the word like a prayer. He looked up through smiling eyes the shade of storm clouds and turned to face his cousin. She saw him then, not as a pale and gangly man, but as a beast of bone and fur beneath a cloak of human skins. “Chaos is the spring that birthed both gods and mortals, and the ocean to which all lively currents flow. Origin and finale. That is the undeniable truth, fair cousin. Yet still, you resist the inescapable End. I would think a goddess who helped set the ocean currents into motion would see how futile it is to rage against the tide.”

“I will persist to the last,” said Arianrhod.

“As will I.”

“I know. That is why I’ve come.” Arianrhod began to pace around Arawn’s desk. From the left side, Arawn appeared as a glittering obsidian cauldron, putrid vapors rising from its base. She moved another few inches; the man Arawn was back, bent and brooding.

“Subtlety was never one of your charms, Arawn. There are rumors throughout the Realm about this latest scheme of yours. I know what you are planning.”

He shrugged a bony shoulder. “So what? It is done! I have already sent my black sparks to the Other Side. The flames will kindle. The cages will open. There is nothing you can do to stop it.”

“Isn’t there?” jeered Arianrhod, one eyebrow arching playfully. “I have stopped you in the past, remember?”

“Long ago, when heroes walked the Earth. But have you peered through your windows lately? Humanity has grown soft, weak, blind. You will find no ally worthy of taking up your cause, Arianrhod. You waste your time coming here today.”

“So confident?” She leaned over the desk and whispered, “You’re not the only one who’s been sitting alone these past ages, plotting in the dark, waiting for the perfect moment to flex your powers once more.”

Arawn stiffened and turned his face away from her, sniffing. He licked his blue lips and breathed deep, then turned back to address her, but Arianrhod was already gone—a white bird in the distance, soaring over the emerald sea, raining feathers as it flew.

“Shut your textbooks. Ignore the timeline on the wall. Forget the dates. Forget the battles. Forget the miserable results on your practice exams. Now, I want you all to ask yourselves: What is history? Yes, Katie?”

“Innit like all that stuff you just said? Like kings and crowns and the dates of battles?”

Riya De Moor hopped up to sit on the front of her desk, palms against its edge, legs swinging gently. She smiled at her students. “That’s just a tiny part of it. History is the accumulation of lives. It’s the story of people like you. That medieval crown in your book was forged by human hands and placed on a human head. That ancient jar behind glass at the British Museum was used to carry water into someone’s home. The mummified pharaoh on the tele was just like you guys. He laughed at jokes, argued with friends, daydreamed, had secrets. Keep that in mind, and history…” She let her gaze wander the room, locking eyes with the teenagers leaning back in their chairs or slumped over their desks, seeking connection. “History comes alive.”

The bell rang. Riya slid stiffly off the desk.

“Remember all that when you’re revising!” Riya called out over the shuffling of books, rucksacks, and chairs. “It might not actually help, but I thought it sounded pretty damn good. Have a safe weekend, guys! Bye, Katie. Bye, Violet. Don’t forget your bag, Rhys. Bye.”

“Laters, Miss Riya!”

As the sea of blue school jumpers receded to the back of the classroom and trickled out the door, Riya limped around her desk, fell into her chair, and sipped at her tepid tea. A bit of commotion at the door caught her eye. Two neon vests were squeezing into the room through the retreating students like chartreuse sails on the blue jumper sea. The vests were framed in black uniforms and two badges gleamed.

A pair of police constables approached the teacher’s desk.

“Hello, Constable Price,” Riya said to the first, pulling herself to her feet. “Haven’t seen you in a while.”

Bronwyn Price—short, mousy-haired, chinless—removed her bowler hat and tucked it under an arm. “‘Lo, Riya! Hope you’re well. Have you met DI Brimble here? Brimble, this is Riya De Moor.”

Riya looked from her friend to the second constable, a wide-set man with enough chins for the whole of the Welsh police force. She shook his massive hand. “Don’t think I’ve had the pleasure.”

Detective Inspector Brimble responded with a grunt.

“I’ve just been telling DI Brimble about you,” said Constable Price. “Best teacher in St. Pyr, so I said! Her pupils really trust her. Why, whenever a teen goes missing, there’s a good bet Miss Riya will track them down and make things right. Isn’t that so, Riya?”

“I do what I can,” said Riya. “What brings you down here?”

“Ah. Well. It’s been a bit of an odd day, to tell you true,” stammered Price. “You know that farmer, lives up near the ruins, name of Dewey Nevitt?”

“Only by reputation. Supposed to be a rather eccentric character.”

“Hm. Well, yes. Seems Nevitt took his digger out this morning to make himself a new potato patch, and the old chap struck something in the soil. At first he thought it was just a big rock, but as he went to dig the thing out, it proved to be…something else.”

“What is it?”

“We’re not sure, but whatever it is, it’s—how do I put it?—an object of historical and archaeological significance.”

Riya crossed her arms, her interest piqued. “No kidding.”

Price nodded vigorously. “Oh yes! Really something. Problem is, old Nevitt is determined to get rid of the thing and plant his damn potatoes. We called the Archeological Council down in Cardiff, but they can’t send a team up to investigate until Monday. The chief’s worried. She asked if we knew any local historians who could come have a look, and I mentioned your name, Riya.”

DI Brimble cleared his throat and grumbled, “Local.”

Riya was used to this sort of thing. Despite having lived in the Welsh village of St. Pyr for the past six years, she was still known as ‘the Londoner’ to the locals, and probably always would be.

“I’d be happy to take a look,” Riya assured them, snatching her coat from her chair and grabbing her cane. The appearance of the cane seemed to draw DI Brimble’s interest in a way nothing else had, and it wasn’t just the rare sight of a thirty-four-year-old with a limp.

Brimble went slightly blue, opened his mouth to speak, shut it again, then spluttered, “Did you really get injured in Iraq? Constable Price told me you did two tours with the Royal Marines!”

“I was in the Royal Military Police, actually,” Riya corrected him, pulling on her coat. “But yeah, I was attached to the Marines in Command 44 starting in ‘07. Though I’m not sure the second tour counts. While on my first patrol back in Iraq, a landmine went off ten feet from where I was standing. Ended my military career with a flash and a roar and a hunk of shrapnel to the lower spine.”

Riya switched off the light and locked up on their way out.

“Couldn’t you have stayed in the service?” asked Price as they walked down the hall. “Been a trainer or recruiter or something?”

“I didn’t fancy it. I miss the uniform, but wearing one behind a desk wasn’t for me. And I like teaching. And I like St. Pyr.”

Heavy clouds hung in pewter curtains over a crisp March afternoon as they set off across the car park. They must have made a strange sight ambling through the chattering ranks of teens: Bronwyn Price bouncing along energetically, an eager cop in her early twenties; DI Brimble, surly, burly, and pushing fifty; Riya De Moor leaning on her cane, keen-eyed and olive-skinned, raven-haired except around the ears where she was going gray.

They took Price’s patrol car and headed north up the winding, cottage-lined road, out of town and into the chilly hills. Riya stared out the back seat window at the old hedge roves, the somber copses of pine, and the grassy slopes, their colors trapped between winter and spring, a soggy mix of beige and marigold.

It began to rain, soft but steady, blurring Riya’s view of the countryside into an oily canvas like those of the impressionist masters.

“So!” croaked DI Brimble, breaking the silence. “How does one get a name like Riya De Moor, anyway?”

“By having a Sikh mother and a Dutch father,” said Riya. “Aren’t you supposed to turn right here?”

“Oh yeah! Cheers,” chirped Price. She turned the car off the pavement, over a cattle grid, and down a muddy gravel road.

They reached the farmstead and Price parked between a low barn and an old farmhouse. Riya stepped out onto the slick rocks and pulled her hood up. Rain patted a tattoo on the car, dripped off the wonky edges of the barn roof, gathered in puddles and soaked into cowpats. Brimble led the way around the corner of the farmhouse, his broad back blocking the women’s view so that Riya’s first impression of the strange scene was auditory. Engines groaned and bumped. Someone shouted curses and instructions, first in English, then in Welsh. Finally Brimble stopped and Riya stepped around him.

An expanse of tilled earth lay between the back of the farmhouse and a field with a broken fence. Two diggers—great big rusted excavating machines, coughing smoke—faced each other, booms extended, buckets lowered, struggling like giant mantises battling over a mate. A pair of chains had been attached to each bucket and ran down to wrap around a very large, very odd object dangling precariously a few feet in the air.

“Damn it all!” boomed Brimble. “They’ve gone and dug the thing right out of the ground!”

The drivers of the two diggers had excavated a great hole in the ground and were attempting to haul the discovery out of it. Riya examined the object where it hung between the diggers. It was ten feet tall and five feet wide, its top half rounded like a sphere, its bottom half tapering off in a sharp curve. Riya thought it looked like a gargantuan terra cotta easter egg.

“My, my,” marveled Price, shaking her head. “Will you look at that, will you? How am I supposed to describe the ruddy thing in my report? Egg-shaped? Is there a technical term for egg-shaped?”

“Ovoid,” Riya told the constable. “But when it’s an upside-down egg shape, the term is obovoid. My god. What is this thing?”

She moved closer, her cane sticking in the mud, and moved to the edge of the hole to stare up at the dangling obovoid. The diggers roared, as did farmer Nevitt and DI Brimble, but Riya was all smiles.

“Look, Bronwyn!” she shouted. “Do you see those markings there below the chains! Old Gaelic, unless I’m mistaken. Could be as old as the sixth century. But then… No! Those symbols down there look almost like… It can’t be Egyptian hieroglyphics!”

Riya took a step back and stabbed at the wet ground with her cane.

“What the hell is this?” she whispered, awestruck. “Where’s it come from? When’s it come from?”

“I say, look out!” shouted Brimble.

Riya looked around and saw both constables running toward her, hands outstretched. She turned back in time to see one of the diggers tilt and fall onto its side. One chain snapped and spit bits of rusty metal. She flinched and ducked as the liberated chain whipped over her head.

The giant clay egg was squeezed in the remaining chains. A web of cracks appeared over its surface. The bottom of the obovoid burst open, spewing dust and clay down into the hole. Straw streamed into the mud. Riya saw what looked like a small box tumble free, then…

She gasped.

A limp human body had slid from the broken egg and into the hole. A moment later, it was lost from view beneath the rain of hay.

“Good lord!” yelped Price. “Did you see that?”

“I saw it!” shouted Brimble. “Dewey, you old twit, get those drivers to move it out of the way! We need to get down there!”

But farmer Nevitt turned on his heel and ran for the front door of the farmhouse, shouting, “I don’t want nuttin to do with this!”

Price came to Riya’s side. They stared at the fallen digger. Only one chain remained holding it to the damaged obovoid, and as they watched, it broke. The other digger careened backward, wheels spinning in the mud, yanking on the obovoid. The egg shattered into heavy pieces.

“Come on,” said Riya, stepping to the edge of the hole and sliding down its slope on the seat of her trousers. Price and Brimble followed clumsily. The three began scooping up mud, straw, and pieces of clay, searching. They found a foot, a shoulder, a face. Soon the mess was cleared away and they crouched, breathing hard, over the naked body of a wrinkled old man.

“Damn and blast,” said Brimble. “We don’t need a historian, we need a bloody coroner! This is a crime scene. A murder! No wonder Nevitt ran, the scoundrel.”

“I don’t think so,” objected Riya, shifting a strand of straw to better look at the corpse’s face. “This obovoid has been buried for a long time, Mr. Brimble. A very long time.”

“Codswallop! Look at the body. It looks as though he died this morning.”

“He could have been preserved somehow, I suppose,” said Riya, but she didn’t think this was likely either. There were no signs of mummification, the limbs were limp, the skin soft.

Overall, the body was in pristine condition. The man was of average height but thin and lanky, and by the way he lay twisted in the fetal position, he looked almost like a child. His head was bald at the top with a great mop of golden-gray curls around the sides and back. His face had once been handsome but now featured a diamond pattern of cracks and wrinkles. He had bristly eyebrows like fat, black caterpillars, a curly white beard, and a great flowing mustache. The ghost of a smile was etched onto his thin lips.

“Fascinating,” said Riya, squinting into the peaceful face. “What’s your story, then?”

The eyes snapped open.

The old man gasped for breath.

“Bloody ridiculous,” whined Detective Inspector Brimble. “This is the most insane thing I’ve done in my whole career. We should be bringing this man straight to the station for booking!”

“On what crime? Trespassing?” asked Price. “Besides, he’s a human being, sir, and he said he was hungry.”

“Is that what he said? All I heard was a lot of blabbering nonsense. And don’t go telling me it was Old English, Miss De Moor! I know English and that wasn’t it. As far as I can tell, this senile twit is just looking for a free meal after that little stunt with the egg. He’s completely nutty in the head.”

“Don’t you mean scrambled, sir?” quipped Price.

“Humph.”

“Well, crazy or not,” Riya told the constables, “I’m ordering him some supper.”

She left Price and Brimble standing by the cafe entrance and walked over to the booth where the old man was seated. He looked up at her curiously. He was dressed in faded flannel and denim from Dewey Nevitt’s moth-ridden wardrobe, and the baggy clothes made his thin form seem almost skeletal. His eyes were large and glassy, one chocolate brown, one forest green. Riya’s grandmother’s eyes had been like that, mismatched and beautiful.

His gaze darted around the cafe, from the faces of other patrons, to the whizzing ceiling fans, to the daily specials scribbled in pink chalk across the blackboard menu above the counter.

“It’s a lovely cafe,” Riya began, hoping to coax a response beyond the rambling grumbles he had uttered back at the farm. He hadn’t spoken a word since they helped him into the back seat of Price’s car. “Like I said before, I’m Riya. Do you have a name?”

He met her eyes and blinked a few times. Then, as if a light was switched on behind his mismatched corneas, his eyes brightened.

“Nay, m’lady!” the man trilled brightly, in a voice so strong and clear that Riya jumped. “I have many names.”

Riya straightened up. By the door, Price and Brimble stopped their bickering to listen in.

“Oh! Many names, you say?” stammered Riya, clearing her throat. “Then what should I call you?”

He leaned back in the booth and rolled up his baggy sleeves, considering the question for a few seconds. “Omicron! Aye, aye. ‘Tis appropriate. Call me Omicron.”

“It’s good to meet you, Omicron. And is that your first name or your last name?”

“Neither, m’lady.”

“Okay then,” said Riya slowly, looking over at Price for support. The constable shrugged. “What are some of your other names?”

“Oh, let me think.” Omicron rubbed a palm across the shiny top of his head. “Here in Britain, most knew me as Merlin. In the Netherlands, they called me Witte Draak. I would tell you what the Franks called me, but”—he glanced at a nearby booth with a cluster of chattering children and their flustered parents—“I’m not sure ’twould be appropriate.”

“Did you say Merlin?” asked Riya. “You think you’re Merlin, as in…as in King Arthur’s magical assistant?”

“Magical assistant?” bellowed Omicron, smacking a hand onto the table so that the salt shaker toppled to the floor. “You save the world a dozen times and unlock magics forgotten for an age, and they remember you as a magical assistant? Magical assistant, indeed!”

He took a deep breath and steadied himself. “Pardon the outburst, m’lady. I’ve a frightful headache. Centuries below the earth’ll do that to a man.”

As he spoke, a waiter came to take their order. The waiter was a young man named Naveen whom Riya had taught a few years back.

“Er—Hey,” said Naveen, bending to pick up the salt shaker. “So what would you guys like?”

“You mean to say this queer, small room is what passes for a Great Hall these days?” gasped Omicron.

Naveen looked over at Riya. “Is he, like, okay?”

Riya sighed. “I’m not sure. Omicron, sir, what would—”

“No sir,” the old man corrected. “Not a knight myself, though I’m friends with many. As for my selection of vittles, I am famished! I’ll begin with a smoky leg of mutton, naturally, and I do rather fancy a pigeon and woodcock pie. Tell me, lad! Can this establishment procure any fine vintages of mead? I’ve never been much of an ale man, myself.”

“We...have Coke.”

Riya put her elbows on the table and leaned into her hands. “Just bring fish and chips and a water. Thanks, Naveen.”

“Whatever.” Naveen lumbered back to the kitchen.

“Alright,” Riya said to herself, summoning that special brand of patience unique to teachers. “Omicron. You were saying you believe yourself to be a medieval sorcerer, I think.”

He nodded brightly.

“Could you show me some magic?” she asked.

“Ah, a doubting Thomas! Alas, nay, m’lady. I’ve not the energy, magical or otherwise, to display sorcery at this time. Perhaps with some meat and spirits in my stomach.”

“Uh-huh,” said Riya. “Then tell me, do you remember why you were inside that thing? The clay egg?”

“Of course I remember! I instructed my apprentices to place spells of frozen death upon my person and seal me in the sacred shape. My present work as Servant of Order was complete, you see, and fearing that my accomplishments would one day be undone by future forces of evil, I preserved myself until I was needed again. And here I am!”

“For someone from the Middle Ages, you speak modern English pretty well.”

“‘Tis easily explained. I am a panglot. I can speak every language, though thrust into a new era like this, it took me a few hours to acclimate.”

“Every language? Quite the talent.”

“Thank you. The real challenge is mastering the First Words—that is, the mother of all languages taught to the first peoples by the gods. After that, ‘tis merely a matter of aligning one’s mind with the evolutionary paths of the child languages. Your modern English is just a twisted bough on a tree I know like an old friend.”

“I see,” said Riya, standing. “Would you excuse me, Omicron? I need to consult with my colleagues.”

She walked over to the police constables. “What do you think?”

“Certifiable,” said Brimble.

“I would tend to agree,” said Riya, “if we hadn’t just seen him emerge from the ground.”

“Even so!”

“Well, maybe it’s one of them internet pranks?” suggested Price. “Maybe some YouTuberist will pop up and yell surprise!”

“Surprise?” repeated Riya, shaking her head. “Surprise as in, Surprise! We baked an old man into a giant egg and buried him in a field! That kind of surprise? What kind of YouTube channels are you watching?”

Price’s cheeks burned pink. “Well, I was only thinking out loud.”

Naveen returned to the booth and set the fish and chips before Omicron, who thanked him, sniffed at the fish, and began to eat.

“Try the chips,” offered Riya, returning to the booth. “They’re made of potatoes. New World food. Never would have been served at the Round Table.”

Omicron nibbled at one chip, then began shoving them into his mouth, three at a time. In less than a minute, the meal was gone and he was gulping the water. He finished with a flourish, wiped his lips with a sleeve, and abruptly stood.

“Let us away, m’lady!” he announced, marching for the door. “I need someone to show me the ins and outs of this neoteric world.”

Brimble started to protest. Riya pulled herself up and tossed a ten pound note onto the table. She grabbed her cane and legged it after Omicron.

“It’s okay!” Riya assured the Detective Inspector. “I’ll stay with him. Bronwyn has my number. We’ll be in contact.”

“But I still say—” Brimble complained as Omicron slid past him and out the door.

“Riya can take care of the old bloke over the weekend,” said Price. “Just don’t leave the village, Riya. We’ll reconnect when the archaeological team comes up on Monday.”

“Right! Cheers, Bronwyn!” Riya called over her shoulder.

She hurried along the edge of the alley, trying to keep up with the spritely old man in baggy flannel. He moved like an excited child, staring at everything, touching everything, agog, befuddled, and amused at each new sight.

“Tell me!” Omicron shouted to the dusk air. “Is there a lord or monarch nearby with a library I might use? I need to catch up on the events of recent centuries.”

“Oh,” wheezed Riya, wincing as she hobbled along beside him. “The village library is closed for renovations.”

“And your own abode, does it not have a collection of manuscripts, maps, histories?”

“Sure, but—“

“Splendid! Then we shall start there.”

There would be a full moon in two days time, but already the moon shone down on St. Pyr with alarming brilliance. A silver wheel in an onyx sky. Riya’s cottage was just south of the village, tucked between a forest and a grassy knoll. The knoll was the main reason she had bought the place. Atop its round crest stood a row of megaliths, like the plates on a stegosaurus’ back. She spent many mornings and evenings staring at the tall stones, and sometimes climbed the hill to get a closer look. She wandered among the megaliths, pondering their primeval purpose and examining with mingled curiosity and annoyance the centuries of graffiti carvings on their granite faces: the sketch of a ship, a vulgar word in Old Welsh, a wonky heart with “T + V” scribbled in its center.

As she stood on the porch and stared at the moonborn shadows of the stones stretched across the knoll and her garden, Riya heard someone walking down the driveway.

“Hello?” she called out, nervous from the day’s unexpected excitement. “Who’s there?”

“Why you shouting?” responded a familiar young voice.

Riya relaxed. “Oh, it’s you, Violet. Sorry.”

Violet Connah emerged from the shadows and walked across the moonlit garden, rucksack swinging, sandals flipping and flopping. Her strawberry hair was tied into its usual messy bun, and in silhouette Riya thought it looked like her fifteen-year-old student was wearing a bird’s nest for a hat.

“I gotta stay here tonight,” said Violet, skipping up the two stairs to the porch. “One of those nights at home, you know. And I need help with this effing report for Lit class. You know Gilgamesh?”

“Huh? Oh, not really. Listen, Violet,” said Riya, sidestepping to halt the girl’s progress, “it’s actually not a great night for me either.”

Violet’s shoulders sank a few inches. She stared at her feet. “I can’t stay? You never said no before, Miss Riya.”

“Well, yes, but…”

By the tungsten glow of the porch light, Riya noticed Violet’s face. A splotch of foundation failed to hide a bruise on the girl’s right cheek.

“Oh, Violet. I’m sorry. I’ve been distracted. I wasn’t thinking. Of course I’ll help you! But I really can’t have you here. Could I drive you over to Trev’s place?”

“We broke up again.”

“Course you did. Er—Your aunt’s in Liverpool? I could get you a ticket.”

“She’s in France with her boyfriend.”

Riya exhaled. “Come on in then. But you should know there’s someone else staying for the night.”

Violet looked up, eyes wide. “Someone else? A man someone else? Oooh! How effing scandalous! And we all thought you were one of those asexual cat ladies.”

“What’s wrong with asexual cat ladies? Besides, it’s not like that. He’s very old, for one thing.”

“What, like forty?”

Violet hopped past Riya and strolled into the cottage. Riya followed, emerging from the low hall into the sitting room right behind Violet, at which point several things happened in quick succession. Violet spotted Omicron stretched leisurely across the book-strewn carpet, shrieked in surprise, and dropped her bag, causing Riya’s cat, Tom Bombadil, to double front flip off the sofa where he had been napping and land atop Omicron’s head. The man started so violently that the copy of A Short History of Nearly Everything he had been reading shot from his hand, soared majestically through the air, and knocked a framed photograph off the wall.

“But!” gasped Violet, clutching a hand over her heart, “he’s…ancient!”

Omicron dislodged the cat from his head, set the hissing animal aside, and stood. “At last, someone perceptive!” He beamed at Violet and bowed low. “Omicron, at your service, m’lady.”

“My lady?” echoed Violet. She smiled. “I think I like that. He’s a bit charming, he is.” She turned and whispered, rather loudly, “Though I still think you could do better, Miss Riya.”

Omicron chuckled. “Aha! The young lady has the wrong idea of Lady Riya’s and my relationship. You see, although Lady Riya certainly seems a very…a very able sort of person—”

“Ooh! Ouch,” muttered Violet.

“—My affections lean more toward the masculine.”

“Oh, you’re gay!” gushed Violet. “Well that makes more sense! I’s wondering why Miss Riya had a man over.”

“Ouch,” said Riya.

“Tell me, Mr. Omicron,” said Violet. “Are you a teacher, too?”

“No!” cut in Riya. “He’s just a, er—”

“Medieval wizard,” answered Omicron.

“…Oh,” trilled Violet, her voice several pitches higher than usual. She had managed to retain her smile, though the bun on her head had gone extra frizzy. “Neat, that.” She turned, teeth clenched in an awkward grin, and mumbled to Riya, “Where’d you find this guy?”

Riya hung her head. “He popped out of an egg.”

Violet’s hair went frizzier still. “I think I’ll get a lemonade,” she said, shuffling off to the kitchen.

Omicron leaned over to pick up the fallen photograph. He stared at it as he collected pieces of glass.

“What scene is this, m’lady? It appears to be a military regiment of sorts.”

Riya crouched beside him. “That picture was taken when I was in the Royal Military Police.” She pointed to herself on the edge of the statuesque brigade, all donning cherry-red berets. “And that woman in the middle is Queen Elizabeth.”

“Current monarch of Britain? And you’re a former warrior? You continue to surprise me, m’lady.”

“Don’t worry about the glass. I can clean it up later.”

“No bother.”

As Riya watched, he set shattered pieces on the picture in their approximate places, mumbled something, and snapped his fingers. The shards jerked together like puzzle pieces, their edges melting into one another. The frame looked good as new.

Riya jerked to her feet, dizzy.

“Wait…” she moaned. “What? What!”

Omicron replaced the frame on its hook. “Ah good. I figured my powers simply needed a few hours to recharge.”

“Omicron,” said Riya slowly. “You just… How did you do that?”

“What? The repair? Old Egyptian trick.”

“Trick?”

“Well, spell.”

Violet came back into the room, popped open her can, and tossed herself onto the sofa. Tom Bombadil jumped up beside her and pushed his whiskered cheek against her leg, eyeing Omicron with clear kitty disdain.

“Why you gone all pale, Miss Riya?” asked Violet, taking a loud sip of lemonade.

When Riya only continued to stare at the magically repaired frame, Omicron said, “Say, Lady Violet—”

“Call me Vi.”

“Lady Vi, would you like to see a demonstration of my magic? I could use the practice.”

Violet snickered behind her drink. “Go for it.”

Omicron took a deep breath, set his feet firmly on the carpet, and cracked his knuckles. He began twisting his hips this way and that, tilting his neck, blinking very fast.

“Quite good magic that,” Violet articulated, like a proud preschool teacher.

Then all at once, Omicron began to change. His body quivered and he fell forward onto hands and knees. The wrinkles in his face stretched as his head elongated, his ears slid upward, his eyes turned outward. Fine brown fur sprouted from his skin. Antlers erupted from his brow, branched, sharpened. His clothes tore away as his torso bulged and his limbs stretched. His hands and feet were hooves, stamping haughtily. His cotton-white tail flicked madly. And from his huge nostrils, steamy breath issued in grunts.

Violet stood up so fast that the poor cat went flying once more.

“Uh, Miss Riya?”

Riya was frozen in place, her mouth hanging open.“Yes, Violet?”

“The old guy turned into a deer.”

“Yes, Violet.”

“He’s a deer now.”

“Yes, Violet.”

“Why is he a deer now?”

The deer stamped and snorted. Tom Bombadil hissed and ran for the hall. Violet took a great gulp of lemonade.

Omicron veered back onto his hind legs, antlers scraping the ceiling, and a moment later he was human again, though his appearance had traded one type of ‘buck’ for another.

“Ta-da!” he sang, arms flung to the sides. “What do you think?”

“I think you’re naked, Omicron!” shouted Riya, shaking herself back to reality and rushing Violet from the room. She returned with a flowered dressing gown and thrust it at Omicron. “And I think you’re…you’re… Bloody hell. I can’t even… You’re the real thing, aren’t you?”

He pulled on the gown. “Aye. I am.”

She took a step closer. The room seemed somehow smaller and dimmer to Riya, and Omicron seemed larger, taller, stronger, even younger—some of his wrinkles had faded.

“This can’t be happening,” said Riya, her voice a scratch in the back of her throat. “What’s going on? Why are you here?”

His smile faded. “I’ll tell you, m’lady, but you might want to sit down.”

“So,” concluded Riya, taking a deep breath, “you’re telling me that it’s all real—the old legends, the gods, all that magic and mayhem.”

Omicron finished his third cup of tea with a smack of the lips. “Aye, they’re real. But ‘tis different now. The gods are far away and have limited ways of affecting life on Earth. But there are ways, and that’s where people like me come into play. Servants of Order. Gate-sealers. Monster-hunters. Secret-keepers.”

“But you make it sound like some divine will woke you up today—or was it yesterday? I’ve lost track of time. That farmer found your obovoid by accident.”

“By accident? You think so?” The old man smirked knowingly. “I’ve yet to determine with certainty the why of my resurrection, but I believe the who behind it is obvious. Arianrhod.”

Riya shook her head. “I don’t know what that is. Ah-ryan-rod?”

“Arianrhod is the Celtic goddess of rebirth. I have had dealings with her before, long ago. Delightful spirit! I suspect ‘twas by her sacred power that I have awoken.”

“But why?”

Omicron twirled one of his golden-gray curls around a finger. They could hear Violet snoring gently on the sitting room sofa.

“Why indeed,” mused Omicron. “I can only guess at the moment. But I sense a sort of…energy, like an itch beneath my skin. An imbalance in the atmosphere. I’ve felt it ever since I awoke, and it’s getting stronger. It seems we’ve reached another tipping point in the history of gods and humankind. Powers are blossoming. Both sides ready themselves for a struggle. Therein lies my purpose. I don’t know what it is the goddess wishes me to do, but I suspect it will take place in this region.”

“In the village or just in Wales?”

“I don’t yet know. Say, might I beg for one final cup of this splendid tea?”

“Sure.” Riya stood and walked to the stove. “What are your immediate plans?”

“To act fast. I’ve wasted enough time already. I must prepare myself and retrieve the tools of my trade. Speaking of which, does m’lady remember seeing a small chest in the obovoid’s remains?”

Riya yawned into the back of a hand. “Hm? Yeah, I do. A wooden box. It fell out right before you did.”

“Where is it now?”

“The inspector picked it up. He couldn’t open it. I suppose it’s back at the police station.”

“Then that’s where I’m headed, as soon as I’ve finished my tea, of course.”

“The station’s closed. You’ll have to wait until Monday.”

The kettle whistled and Riya hurried to pull it off the burner before it woke Violet. She filled a mug, then on reflection, a second and third.

“Something tells me I won’t be able to talk you out of marching down to the station tonight, will I?” asked Riya.

“Nay, m’lady.”

“Then I’m coming too. I promised Bronwyn that I’d watch after you.”

“Your presence would be gladly welcome.”

“Wh-what about me?” asked a groggy Violet, stumbling into the kitchen. “Heard the tea… What time is it? Where you going?”

“It’s two in the morning,” said Riya, checking the microwave clock. “Sorry to wake you, Violet. Omicron needs something down at the police station.”

Omicron rubbed his hands together excitedly. “We’re robbing a constable’s keep!”

“Well, alright then!” said Violet, perking up. “Sounds like fun. I’m in!”

“We are not going to break in,” said Riya. “I’ll call Bronwyn on the way and have her meet us there. And if you insist on tagging along, Violet, you will wait in the car.”

“Ah, no! Not that smelly old Nova,” the girl whined.

“I’ll be sure to upgrade to an Aston Martin when I get my next raise.”

“Just let me go in with you two, Miss Riya!”

“You’ll wait in the car.”

Recharged with Earl Gray, they all pulled on winter coats and left the cottage to squeeze into Riya’s mustard-colored ’93 Vauxhall Nova.

Riya parked around the corner from the police station and jammed a finger onto her phone screen irritably.

“Why isn’t she answering!” She shoved the phone into her coat pocket.

Omicron opened the passenger side door and stepped out. “You tried contacting your constable friend, but now ‘tis time I go in.”

“You can’t. It’ll be locked.”

Omicron chortled. “Poppycock.”

As he sauntered off, Riya groaned and opened her own door. “Stay here, Violet,” she said to the back seat. “And—Are you posting something online? You know you could get me fired!”

“I’s only texting Trev. I think we might be getting back together.”

“Course you are.”

She shut her door gently and walked along the cobblestone road, the click of her cane echoing through the claustrophobic labyrinth of alleyways, storefronts, rubbish bins, parked cars, and empty windows that made up the center of the village.

“Are you chatting with that door handle, Omicron?” Riya asked in a whisper as she approached the front of the station.

Omicron shushed her and gave the door a little stroke. “Not chatting, charming,” he said, and snapped his fingers. The doorknob clicked and twisted on its own. The door swung inward.

Riya reached out and grabbed the door before Omicron could enter. “You can’t just go busting into places! We’ll both get arrested.”

“Arrested?” The airiness and mirth had gone from his voice. “You said it yourself, m’lady. Gods, magic, mayhem. All real. All dangerous. That is what we’re up against. Not local ordinances. If you wish to continue being a part of this misadventure, you best expand your mind and get your priorities straight.”

He ducked under her arm and slipped inside. After a moment, Riya followed.

“Don’t turn on the lights,” she said. “It’ll alert the neighbors. Here, I brought a torch.”

She turned on the torch and they moved about the room, peering behind the reception desk, into the cubicles, and into the empty cells. While searching the chief constable’s office in the back of the station, they found the wooden chest tucked away in a corner beneath a neon vest.

“Ah, there you are, darling!” Omicron lifted the chest onto the chief’s desk.

Riya was about to ask how to open the chest, not seeing any lid, but Omicron had already done so—somehow. He was pulling out folded garments of silk and leather.

“Finally, some real clothes again. Boots and all!”

“We better not have broken in here just to get you some new clothes.”

“Not just any clothes. Specifically, this.” He reached into the bottom of the chest and lifted something out.

Riya aimed her torch. “What is it?”

“The Gauntlet of Camelot. It is, if I do say so myself, one of the greatest devices ever dreamed up. Certainly one of my finest inventions.”

Riya stepped closer. She had to admit that the gauntlet was a thing of beauty. It had a leather wrist guard engraved with Celtic symbols, with leather straps and silver buckles. The guard was attached to a brass-scaled glove with leather fingers. On the back of the hand, fixed in place, was a small, egg-shaped gem, deep purple with bands of brown and black.

“You see that ovoid gem? It’s a polished piece of petrified wood,” whispered Omicron, wonder plain in his voice. “And it is a piece of true legend. That gem gave King Arthur’s sword its power. I saw a story in one of your history books, m’lady, about the sword in the stone? It seems historians got it back to front. ‘Twas not the sword in the stone, but the stone in the sword. This gem, fixed in the hilt of Excalibur, gave Arthur an enchanted power on the battlefield.”

Riya’s breathing was slow, deep. Her cheeks grew warm. “Really… I’ll be damned. How’d it end up in your gauntlet?”

Omicron’s expression hardened. “When my king was slain in the Battle of Camlann by his bastard son Mordred, Arthur’s sword was broken. The vultures of the battlefield fought over the pieces of the blade, but I knew that its true power was in the ovoid stone. I retrieved it, and later, built this.”

“And what does it do?”

“If one is wearing the gauntlet, any weapon they hold in their hand will have its potency increased exponentially.”

“Neat trick, if it works.”

“Oh, it works.” He set down the gauntlet and lifted a silken shirt. “Now then, I am getting changed.”

Riya straightened up. “Thanks for warning me this time.”

She left the office, shutting the door behind her, and stood in the main station.

“This is bloody crazy,” she said aloud. She pulled out her phone to try Bronwyn Price again. The phone rang once, twice, three times, then beeped into voicemail. “Hey Bronwyn. It’s Riya again. I—er—don’t really know how to say this, but I’m actually standing in…in… Hang on… Something’s here… Something… Igottacallyouback—”

Riya dropped the phone and her body snapped into a defensive position. She aimed her torch like a weapon, eyes peeled. She had heard something and a fragment of her mind, locked forever in military mode, set her whole body on red alert.

Spying a truncheon left out on a desk, Riya grabbed it and revolved slowly, torch beam scanning the room.

A snarl. A flash of green eyes.

Something huge and hairy erupted from the darkness and slammed into Riya. She tripped over a chair and cracked her head against a desk. Rolling up onto her knees and ignoring the searing pain in her lower back and her head, she swung the truncheon just as her attacker pounced. The weapon vibrated in her hand as it struck its target. The creature didn’t budge.

Riya scooted backward on her knees, squinting at the shape advancing on her, feeling on the ground for her torch. She found it and aimed the beam. For one terrifying second, she saw the light reflect in emerald-green eyes, glint off sharp teeth, play across twitching ears and a hunched back covered in thick black quills. It was like a dog, but so much larger, more gruesome, more revolting than any breed she knew. And its eyes glowed.

The beast leaped at her.

Riya whipped up the truncheon and held it tight in both hands as the thing fell upon her. She was flattened, pinned under its clawed feet. The creature’s jaw fixed around the truncheon, snapping furiously, sharp teeth straining to chew their way through and sink into her face. She pushed back with all her might but already her arms were shaking. Milky saliva dripped onto Riya’s face, sizzling hot.

“Omicron!” Riya screamed.

And he was there, standing beside her, draped in fine clothes, dark boots, and a leather cloak. Omicron raised his right hand, now donning the glittering Gauntlet of Camelot. He squeezed his hand into a fist. He struck.

The blow came down like a hurricane, crashing into the creature’s side, flinging it off of Riya and into a nearby shelf, which shattered. As the beast rose, shaking and drooling, Riya forced herself up and stood beside Omicron.

“Mind if I borrow that?” he asked her coolly, nodding at the truncheon in her hands.

She handed it over. Omicron held it out like a sword, and Riya experienced a very odd sensation. As she stared at the truncheon, she saw that it was still three feet long, black, with teeth marks on its center. Yet at the same time, it seemed to have become something else—a deadly club, six feet long, glowing blue and haloed with a fringe of rainbow. It was as if a magical, ghostly shell encased the simple weapon.

The creature crouched, snarled, pounced. Omicron swung his weapon with a wordless battle cry. The creature was blasted from the air, crashed through a window, and slumped onto the street outside. Riya heard glass raining down onto the cobblestones.

“Holy shit! What is that thing?”

“A gwyllgi,” sneered Omicron. “A hound of hell! No doubt sent through some rift in the fabric between realms to make trouble for us. It must have sensed the power of the gauntlet. Come! I can feel the presence of at least two more outside.”

“Outside?” gasped Riya. “Violet!”

She ran, leaving her cane behind, out into the cold night air.

“Violet!”

“Oi!” Violet called back, rolling down the back seat window. “Someone just broke a window—”

“Start the damn car!”

Violet was looking at Riya and so didn’t see the green eyes approaching from up the road. A gwyllgi—Riya didn’t know if it was the one from inside or another—was crouched low and moving fast. Riya ran with awkward steps, teeth gritted against the pain in her spine. She reached the car a second before the hound. She grabbed the driver’s side door and yanked it open into the creature’s path. The gwyllgi snarled and bucked, wrenching off the door so that it clattered onto the street. Violet turned the key as Riya leaped behind the steering wheel, slammed the stick into reverse, and pounded her foot onto the accelerator.

Riya had just noticed something rushing into sight in the rearview mirror when the car collided with a second gwyllgi. The back windscreen shattered and the beast rolled over the vehicle, landing ahead of them, legs kicking.

“Effing ‘ell!” shrieked Violet, throwing her hands over her head.

“Omicron!” Riya shouted, watching the two hounds in the road advance once more.

The backdoor opened and Omicron climbed in next to Violet, the truncheon now in his left hand and without any magical power.

“Shall we depart?” he asked casually.

The wheels squealed as the car accelerated around the snarling beasts and tore down the winding road.

“What’s happening?” simpered Violet. “Did you see the size of that dog?”

“Where are you taking us, m’lady?” asked Omicron.

“Go to the police!” shouted Violet.

“We just came from the bloody police station!” Riya shrieked, swerving the car into a shortcut that obliterated a postbox and three azalea bushes. “We’re going back to my place. There’s something I need.”

In the rearview mirror, the three gwyllgi pursued them like speeding cheetahs. One caught up and ran along the car’s left side, snapping its jaws at the windows. Another came alongside the car’s right, glaring at Riya through the missing door with eyes like shamrock flames. Riya jerked the wheel right and left. The car swerved and tilted, slamming into one hound and then the other. Both gwyllgi fell back, yelping.

“We’re almost there!” shouted Riya. “Omicron! I need you to buy me some time! Can you do that?”

“Right ho.”

Omicron twisted in his seat, flexed the fingers of his gauntleted hand, and cupping the hand in front of his mouth, blew. His breath whistled out the shattered back windscreen. The air behind the car brightened in a magically-appearing cloud of silver shapes. The phantoms spun and danced, formless and playful, and the galloping gwyllgi leaped and snapped their jaws at the light.

“How long will it distract them?” asked Riya, glancing at the magical shapes in her mirror.

“Perhaps a minute.”

Riya nodded. “Okay. Okay, okay. I got this.”

She swerved down her street and the moonlit megaliths came into view. The car bumped and rattled down the hill and crunched to a stop in front of her cottage.

Riya hurtled herself from the car and through the front door, then into the bedroom. She threw herself on the floor beside her bed and pulled out a locker from underneath it. She entered the code and opened the locker. Setting aside a folder of official documents detailing her unique permission to own and use the objects within, Riya lifted out a belt and holster. Rising, she fixed the belt around her waist and stomped from the cottage.

“Whoa,” said Violet from the back seat as her teacher emerged. “You look…different.”

Riya popped orange earplugs into her ears. She pulled a pistol from her holster, slid in a 15-round magazine, and yanked back the slide to load the first cartridge into the chamber.

“What tool is this then?” asked Omicron, stepping from the car and eyeing the pistol doubtfully. “An arm of fire?”

“It’s a Sig Sauer P226 MK25 9mm. And it’s gonna demolish those hounds.”

“Hm. Right,” mumbled Omicron, moving the truncheon to his right hand so that the ghostly blue light returned.

“Cover your ears, Violet. You too, old man, if you know what’s good for you.”

Two of the gwyllgi appeared at the end of the driveway and skidded down the hill. Riya delivered six shots in quick succession, the pistol thundering in her hand, the bullets pelting at the first hound. It squealed, fell, rolled in a spray of shimmering green blood. As it rose drunkenly and hobbled sideways, dripping blood, Riya adjusted her aim and shot three times at the second hound. It scurried off the driveway to hide in the woods. Five more shots rang out, blasting off chunks of tree bark. Spent cartridge cases rained into the grass at Riya’s feet.

“Miss Riya!” shouted Violet. “On your left!”

The third and final gwyllgi darted from the darkness at the side of the garden and pounced. It soared through the air, claws extended, jaws open, and just as it was about to land on Riya’s shoulders, she spun and fired her last bullet into its open mouth. Emerald blood misted the air. The creature flipped backward and crashed down onto the slick grass.

Riya ejected the pistol’s magazine, loaded another from her belt, and pushed the slide release.

“Ohmygod!” squeaked Violet. “Miss Riya’s a badass.”

Omicron approached the fallen gwyllgi and brought his glowing truncheon down upon its bleeding head, smashing away any remaining life.

Riya turned and aimed at the first two hounds, both of which stalked in menacing circles at the edge of the garden, crouched and bleeding.

“There’s no need,” said Omicron. “The brutes know you’ve won the night. They’ll gather their dead and descend back into the darkness from whence they came.” He looked over at Riya and shook his head, his expression dumbstruck. “My, my. ‘Tis nice to finally meet Lady Riya the Warrior.”

Riya rounded on him, sliding her pistol into its holster and glaring into his face.

“You think this is a game to me?” she shouted. “Violet is a child! She is one of my students. She could have been killed tonight!”

“Aye, well—” Omicron began, but Riya cut him off.

“Whatever the hell is going on here, whatever the hell you’ve got us mixed up in, I need to know everything. Do you hear me, Omicron?”

“Of course, of course.” He watched as one of the hounds came forward, tail tucked between its legs. It bent to bite its fallen comrade’s tail and dragged the body into the shadows. “I had suspicions as to why Arianrhod awoke me. I thought perhaps one of the other gods was planning some sinister scheme and ‘twas my job to stop them. This confirms my fears. He is behind tonight’s horror.”

“Who?”

Omicron closed his eyes and inhaled the cold night air. “The gwyllgi have forever been the servants…of Arawn.”

The hair on the back of Riya’s neck stood on end. “I’ve heard of that one. Celtic god of war and chaos, right? And ruler of the underworld?”

“Indeed. Not a pleasant fellow. In the old days, he had a thing for monsters—used to breed them in his land, Annwn, and set them loose upon the Earth. Arawn must be regaining some of his old powers. He must be planning to awaken the old monsters.”

Riya patted the P226 at her side. “Well, if his monsters can be taken out with a headshot, it shouldn’t be too hard to handle them.”

Omicron looked at her, his lips pursed and brow furrowed. “These aren’t monsters, m’lady! The gwyllgi are but minions, furry little henchmen to be Arawn’s eyes as he prepares for the true assault.”

“But you said—”

“I said he would release a monster, probably nearby, probably soon. But he hasn’t…yet.”

Riya peered around her garden, up the megalith-crested hill, into the trees. “You really think there’s some great primeval beast buried under St. Pyr, sleeping soundly?”

“Aye, m’lady, and if I’m not wrong, ‘tis about to wake up.”

Sunlight was slicing through the curtains when Riya awoke from a deep and dreamless sleep. She was surprised when she saw the clock. She had expected to be roused in the early morning by the sounds of sirens and the rough hands of constables dragging her out of bed and down to the ruined police station. But no. The cottage was cool, quiet, and smelled of sausages.

She yawned as she stepped into the kitchen. The sink was full of dishes. Violet sat at the table, squinting at the screen of Riya’s laptop. Past the sitting room door frame, Riya could see Omicron’s bare feet extending over the sofa armrest.

“This is a sight to behold,” said Riya. “Violet Connah is reading history articles on Wikipedia, while Omicron the sorcerer eats sausage and watches… Is that Indiana Jones? Strange scene to wake up to. Say, why aren’t we in jail?”

“Oh that!” Omicron paused his movie and sat up to peer into the kitchen. “It seems this reawakened body of mine requires no sleep whatsoever. Convenient, nay? So I took the liberty of slipping out after you ladies were asleep and tidying up the station.”

“Tidying up?”

“Looks good as new! More or less. And I brought back your mobile telephone and cane. Oh, and I saw the file they had about my obovoid, so I made a quick call to the Cardiff Archaeological Council first thing this morning. I assured them that they wouldn’t need to come up on Monday after all, as the events reported to them yesterday were clearly a hoax. As long as you can convince your constable friend that there’s no need for further inquiry, I think we are in the clear to get on with our monstrous search.”

“I’m the one searching,” complained Violet from the table. “He’s just been streaming movies all day! He might have been a genius back in the Dark Ages or whatever, but he can’t even use a keyboard!”

Omicron nibbled the sausage on his fork and grimaced. “‘Tis true! I’ve no knack for this new brand of sorcery you call computer science. Besides, it is important for me to catch up on the latest ballads and epics of our world!” He pushed play and settled back on the sofa.

Riya leaned over Violet’s shoulder. The screen showed a list of Celtic legendary creatures.

“Find anything?”

“Lots, but most of it sounds like rubbish. But I did see something about those crazy gwiggly dog things from last night.”

Riya regarded her student carefully. “You seem to be taking all this surprisingly well. The magic, the creatures. I feel like I can barely hold it together myself. It’s like a dream or something.”

“It’s cool! And I’s so scared last night, and so busy trying not to piss myself, that I didn’t think to take any pics! That’s why I want to find this monster Omicron keeps talking about. Hey Omicron, could we be looking for a henwen?”

“Nay, my dear, I don’t believe that Arawn will be resurrecting any fairy pigs. But good try! Keep searching.”

Riya ate a quick breakfast and showered.

It was with a renewed sense of excitement that she, Omicron, and Violet loaded into the Nova. Omicron had magically repaired most of the damage to the car, but failing to understand the exact mechanics of it, had neglected to reattach the driver’s side door in a manner that allowed it to be opened. Riya had to slide her stiff legs through the window and slump awkwardly into the seat. Violet found this highly amusing. Riya did not.

As they drove, Omicron explained further research he wished Violet to tackle and she agreed to try when she could get online.

They dropped Violet off in the village center to meet up with friends—“I promise I won’t tell them nothing, I won’t. They’d just say I had a bad trip, anyways!”—and set off to search the area for signs of Arawn’s monster.

“Where to first?” asked Riya.

Omicron rolled down the car window and inhaled a breath of village air. “West and north, I think. Into the high hills. I want to look down at this landscape from above. I want to see it.”

They drove for an hour to the edge of Snowdonia National Park, where Omicron told Riya to pull over. He got out, paced along the road with his hands behind his back, looked into the misty faces of the forested hills, then peered over them to the distant snowy peaks.

“Higher,” he said as he climbed back into the car.

Half an hour later, Riya pulled into a petrol station. She went in to pay and go to the toilets, and when she came back to the car, she found Omicron sitting on the boot, one hand outstretched and wearing the Gauntlet of Camelot. His eyes were closed. His lips were moving. Riya looked past him but saw only a wide expanse of hilly farms, a maze of hedge roves, a foggy slice of a foggy world.

“What are you doing?”

“Looking,” he whispered. “We should go east, I think! Back toward St. Pyr. The energies were stronger there.”

They drove, Riya offering ideas, pointing at signs to various castles and ruins, bringing up old legends she had half forgotten, but the old man wished only to sniff the air, to stare at trees and passing clouds, to mumble strange words to himself.

They passed through the heart of St. Pyr and continued up to Dewey Nevitt’s farm. From there, they went to the ruins of Wydstow Castle, explored the grounds, and chatted with the tour guide in the gift shop.

“He might of told us more,” complained Riya as she slumped through the car window afterward and started the ignition, “if you hadn’t been flirting with him so much.”

“Apologies, m’lady. But he was so very cute.”

“Yeah, he was.” She turned south. “We’re going home for now. I’m hungry, my back hurts, and it’s getting late.”

Riya texted Violet when they arrived at the cottage and Violet responded with the message that she would be spending the night with Trev—“Course you are”—so Riya headed to her bed with a bag of crisps. She lay on top of the covers eating and listening to the television in the next room until she fell asleep.

Riya awoke covered in crumbs, being shaken by an excited Omicron shouting something about sensing psychic tremors to the south. So she yawned and showered and they set off once more, this time driving through flat country and cold rain, looking for something Riya didn’t fully understand. It was all so strange to her and had too many uncomfortable implications.

Her world was a world written in books and on timelines—despite the inspiring speeches she gave to her classes—but everything Omicron was telling her challenged that perspective. It seemed that no matter how talented a historian, how passionate, how authentic their desire to learn the truth might be, they could only ever see one side of history. The other side—those realms of deities and underworlds and dark creatures—lurked between the pages of every human story, unseen, uncredited, checked only by those like Omicron. History, it seemed, was full of monsters after all.

By the time they returned to Riya’s cottage on Sunday evening, she’d had to refill the petrol tank three times. Her back felt as though she had gone through a particularly challenging bout of physiotherapy. She needed to check over the exams for class in the morning. She needed sleep. She needed distraction. She got none of these things.

“What are we missing, goddess dammit! What haven’t I thought of?” huffed Omicron, collapsing onto the sofa, much to the distress of Tom Bombadil, who had been curled up asleep.

“I’ve no idea,” sighed Riya, pulling out her pistol from underneath her coat to secure it back in the locker for the night, “but I’ve got to get ready for tomorrow’s class.”

Omicron sat up, the cat biting at the sleeve of his cloak. “History class,” he muttered. His eyes swiveled to look at the weapon in Riya’s hand. “A history scholar and a warrior… I wonder.”

“What are you on about?”

He stood, a mad gleam in his eyes. “Here I am wandering blindly around the region, looking for clues, when the search was done for me. I was already brought to where I needed to be!”

“Nay, m’lady. I mean you. Riya De Moor is the answer.”

“Don’t you have any other weapons in this place?” he shouted. “A mace? An axe? A scythe?”

“For scything, of course!” Omicron ran into the sitting room and began tossing aside couch cushions and the pictures on the wall.

“Oh aye, by all means, lock the front door! That’ll stop it!”

“No need to be nasty.”

“Uh. Fly? Breathe fire? So is it really a—”

He pulled the knife from his pocket with his left hand, weighed the blade in his palm, then flipped it in the air to catch in his gauntleted right hand. Riya stared at the eight inches of steel and the plastic handle—and at the gleaming ghost of a blue-silver sword projected over and around it, casting ethereal light across the darkening garden.

She took a deep breath, let her cane fall to the ground, and raised her pistol.

It groaned, beat a clawed foot against the ground, and began to pull itself upright. Leathery wings folded against its side, streaked with gray slime. Its ghastly head reared and snorted, red eyes blinking. Its horns were like spikes of granite. Its back was lined with a row of megaliths along the spine, each scratched with centuries of graffiti.

Omicron raised his magic blade in both hands.

“Awake, ye pest of night! Awake and look with eyes of fire on the source of your destruction! See the blade that will sever your hideous head from its scaly shoulders! This blade…” He paused and looked over at Riya. “What do you call it?”

“It’s a bread knife.”

Omicron scowled and turned back to the dragon. “The deadly blade of…of Bread Knife will be the last thing you see before your demon soul is flung down into the Abyssal Sea! Here stands Omicron! “I teach at the local secondary school. Sixth form history.”

“Well that’s not going to intimidate it!” he hissed back.

The dragon gave a great smokey cough, beat its neck from side to side, flapped its huge wings feebly.

“Awake and face Death!” bellowed Omicron, taking a step forward. “Or else turn, lay yourself down, drift back into your diabolical dreams. We will cover you with earth. Riya put her hands over her ears. The blast of sound knocked her a pace backward.

“Can I try shooting it now?” she asked, when the roaring ceased.

“By all means,” said Omicron.

He launched himself forward and to the left, running with a speed and agility any Royal Marine would be jealous of. Riya aimed her pistol into the dragon’s face and fired one shot after another, limping forward as her finger squeezed the trigger, ears ringing. The bullets pinged off the dragon’s scales in a shower of sparks. It sneered, snarled, looked from Omicron to Riya and back again, then turned its colossal body and charged for the old man.

Omicron ducked and rolled under its galloping legs. He slid on his knees behind the dragon and spun to his feet.

“Watch the tail!” Riya shouted, still firing.

It swung its tail upward, flinging Omicron high in the air. He tumbled onto the ground, shook himself, stood.

His weapon, now an ordinary bread knife, remained lodged in the dragon’s tail, swinging twenty feet off the ground.

“I need a weapon!” he shouted.

Riya reloaded and began emptying her next magazine at the dragon’s belly, its shoulders, its ears, trying to find a weak spot. “Aren’t you a ruddy sorcerer?”

“Oh, right ho!”

Omicron fell to his hands and knees, arched his back, stretched his neck. Fur sprouted across his skin and his limbs stretched. Antlers forked into being. Hooves kicked off his boots and gauntlet. Most of his other clothes tore away, but the leather cloak remained hooked around his neck, and as the deer galloped forward and charged the dragon from behind, the cloak flowed like a cape.

Riya stopped firing as Omicron galloped into her line of sight. The deer ducked gracefully below another swipe of the tail and leaped onto the dragon’s back. It drove its sharp antlers into the monster, right between its wings, bucking, tearing, spraying ruby blood into the evening air. The dragon reared onto its hind legs, rocking its body forward and backward, then with one mighty beat of its wings, it flew ten feet off the ground, tilted backward, and let itself fall with a great crunch.

“Omicron!” Riya screamed, limping forward as the dragon rolled back to its feet. The wounded form of the wizard, now half man, half deer, lay among the stone and sod, twitching under his cloak.

The dragon let out a cough of victorious smoke and turned on the woman. It crouched low to the ground and leered its head forward, jaws snapping. Riya spun, the rough snout scraping along her tumbling body, and managed to grab hold of a tooth. She pulled herself up against the side of the dragon’s head, placed the barrel of her pistol against its right eye, and pulled the trigger.

As the dragon roared and scraped with a clawed foot at its ruined eye, Riya pulled herself up and limped as fast as she could to where Omicron’s clothes lay in tatters. She set down her pistol, lifted the Gauntlet of Camelot, and slammed it onto her right hand.

“This had better work,” she grunted, tightening the buckles and grabbing her P226 in her left hand.

She stood with a groan.

She shifted the gun to her right hand, tightened her gauntleted fingers on the grip, and felt her hand go strangely numb and warm.

“History came alive.” She raised the pistol, marveling at the magical cannon it had become, etched with swirls of ghost-blue light, shining in her fist. “And now I’m gonna blow its goddess-damn head off.”

“Good goddess!” he moaned. “What happened?”

Riya came in with two steaming mugs. “A dragon fell on you. I’m amazed you’re still alive. Tea?”

He shook his head, cringing with the gesture.

All the energy and strength Omicron had gained since his dramatic arrival in the present had vanished. He looked thin and hunched again, bruised, more wrinkled than ever.

“Did we win?” he asked weakly.

“I won. With a headshot, I’ll have you know. Though the gauntlet helped.”

He slid his trembling legs over the edge of the sofa and tried to stand.

“Whoa. Slow down. You need rest,” said Riya, setting down the mugs and rushing to help him. “It’s done. The monster’s dead.”

“One monster. Nay, nay. Arawn began his assault in lands where he used to be worshipped—far simpler that way—but he’s only just getting started. This globe will rock with the pounding of monstrous paws.”

Riya took his hand and helped him to his feet, then wrapped the sheet around him like a toga.

“Does Arianrhod really expect one old sorcerer to deal with all that?” asked Riya.

“Of course not! One monster in Wales, one resurrected warrior. That’s how it will go. Wherever Arawn awakens a monster, there too, Arianrhod will have a warrior ready. God versus Goddess. “We?”

Outside, the sound of a siren grew louder. Riya glanced at the curtains and saw flashes of blue light through the cloth.

She sighed. “Shit. Now I have to explain why there’s a dragon corpse in my garden.”

Helping one another with arms draped over shoulders, Riya and Omicron hobbled onto the porch, shielding their eyes from the glare of headlights shining in the night. A lone patrol car pulled to a stop in the driveway.

“Riya? Are you alright? There was an earthquake! Can you believe it?” called out Bronwyn Price’s voice. The constable walked to the porch. She was alone. “What happened to you two? You look terrible!”

Riya tried to grin. “Long story.”

Price lifted a torch from her belt and scanned the property. “Good lord! The quake took down the old hill, it did! Incredible! And…er...Riya?” She pointed at the colossal gruesome shape of the dragon. It lay in the grass, belly up, neck twisted, wings stuck in the branches of ruined trees. “I don’t… What is…?”

Riya reached out a hand and gently pushed the torch down to aim at their feet.

“Bronwyn. You can’t… I mean, it’s complicated.”

Price’s body had gone stiff. “Complicated? Oh. But… Do I…do I want to know what happened here?”

Riya exhaled. “No, I don’t think you do. It’s best you move along. This is something we need to handle. Trust me. You check on the neighbors. I’m sure they’re shaken from the…the earthquake.”

“Okay then… Right.”

Price did not blink or look in the direction of the dragon as she hurried to her car and climbed in. She reversed at high speed, wheels squealing.

“What are we supposed to do about the dragon, anyway?” Riya asked Omicron.

“I’ve got some old colleagues I can call. They’ll take care of it.”

“Oi!” shouted a voice from the darkness. “Watch where you’re driving, you daft copper!”

Violet was at the end of the driveway sidestepping the reversing patrol car.

“What’s she doing here?” said Riya, walking down the steps to meet the girl.

“When the whole bloody ground started shaking, I knew it had to be you two,” asserted Violet, strolling toward them. “Cheese and crackers! Look at that thing! It real?”

“Sure is.”

“Wow. Here let me… Oh crap! My battery’s dead!”

“What are you doing here, Violet?”

“Well I came to check on you, Miss Riya, didn’t I? Besides, I finished up that research for Omicron. Here! I think this is what you’re after.”

She handed Omicron a few folded sheets of printed paper, eyeing his bruises and wrinkles with mingled concern and horror.

“Many thanks, Lady Vi! Let’s see here.” Omicron squinted in the porchlight and scanned each page in turn, mumbling as he read. “Trinity Site… Twenty-two kilotons… Ancient burial ground… Aye, aye. This looks right. This confirms my feelings.”

“What are you on about now?” asked Riya.

“Our next destination, m’lady!” said Omicron, some of the life and color returning to his cheeks. “We will leave as soon as a passage can be arranged.”

“Well I can’t just leave!” Riya protested. “I have my classes! There’re exams in the morning.”

“Exams! Bah!” laughed Omicron. “All this talk about studying history, and I’m giving you the chance of changing history! Can the two really compare?”

“Where would we be going anyway?”

He jabbed a finger at the paper. “To the land of enchantment!”

“Where’s that? Avalon?”

“Nay, not bloody Avalon! The land of enchantment is the state motto for New Mexico in America. So pack a bag, Lady Riya! We’re off to the New World.”

Omicron strutted back to the porch, tugging on his makeshift toga.

Riya’s fingers still tingled from firing the magic pistol. She scanned the night around her. The damaged trees. The ruined garden. The missing hill. And the corpse, so undeniably real, with broken wings and toppled, claw-rimmed limbs. The head was splayed open like a gruesome flower, gooey innards just visible in moonlit bands of color, the odor rich, pungent, sickly sweet.

“You alright, Miss Riya?”

“I think so, Vi. Yeah. Well, come on. Let’s get inside. I’ll put the kettle on. Looks like I’ve got some plans to make.”

16 July 1945

Jornada Del Muerto Desert, 230 miles south of Los Alamos, New Mexico

Private Nez stuck a cigarette between his chapped lips. The heavy black goggles he and his fellow soldiers were instructed to wear itched horribly. Over the tinny speakers, the countdown continued.

“Twenty-seven. Twenty-six. Twenty-five. Twenty-four…”

“You ready for this shit?” someone asked.

Nez shrugged. He didn’t care much either way and half expected the experiment to go belly-up. Wouldn’t that show the top brass, all those pompous officers and featherbrained scientists. All Nez wanted was for the assignment to be complete so he could get a break from the unforgiving New Mexican sun.

“Thirteen. Twelve. Eleven. Ten…”

They called it the Manhattan Project, but there was nothing cosmopolitan about this assignment. Nez and the other soldiers were sworn to secrecy; they couldn’t even call their sweethearts. Long hours hauling equipment off trucks and over rocks. Sweaty nights. Lukewarm beer. The end couldn’t come soon enough.

Nez lit his cigarette with a Zippo and took a drag. He leaned forward beside the others, his elbows against the bunker’s sandbag wall. All of their goggles were aimed over the flat expanse of sand, cactus, and juniper.

“Four. Three. Two. One—”

Cold light. Hot wind. A flash and a wheeze and a growing rumble.

“Holy shit,” someone whimpered. “Will ya look at that?”

The starburst of orange melted into a towering mushroom cloud, a mountain of energy crowned with rings of dazzling white. The landscape rippled—a spreading sandstorm preceded by a deadly shock wave.

“Whoa. Check out the… Nez? Nez!”

Some of the others had finally noticed Private Nez. He lay twitching at the foot of the sandbags, goggles askew, foamy saliva spilling from his mouth. On the ground beside his trembling body, his cigarette issued a thread of twisting smoke.

“Shit, Nez! What’s happening?”

Gloved hands pulled him to a sitting position. The bunker was vibrating like a bell, but Nez was shaking even harder.

“See them…” he moaned. “Did you…see them?”

“You been drinking, Nezzie? What’s happening, man? Stay with us.”

They took off his goggles and forced a canteen to his mouth. He spluttered and coughed.

“In the explosion!” Nez shrieked. “Rising up. Giants, spirits. I saw their bodies! Shoulders, breasts, bright eyes!”

“Damn, Nez! You’re gonna get yourself thrown in a padded room, man, talking like that.”

“Don’t you understand!” he screamed. “We did something! That goddamn bomb did something. Woke something up. Released them. Twinned beauty and terror.”

The other soldiers exchanged anxious glances.

“This Indian’s been out in the sun too long,” someone grunted rudely.

Nez’s teeth chattered. Tears fell, unchecked, from his bloodshot eyes. A line of dark blood ran from his left nostril and trickled over his cracked lips.

“I saw,” he repeated. “And I heard…I heard her laughing.”

And then he was laughing, too. A crazy laugh that cut through the shrill nuclear blare all around them and died in the sand-swept air.

Present day

Riya peered through the airplane window at the gently curved horizon where the Atlantic met the sky. She pulled down the plastic shade and settled back in her seat. In the seat beside her, Omicron hummed quietly to himself as he read a comic book.

Reaching into her jacket pocket, Riya slid out two items and looked them over, considering. The first was a shiny black credit card with a gold etching of a scarab. Omicron had simply called it ‘the company card.’ Riya had successfully used the card to purchase their tickets at Heathrow. The second item was a burgundy UK Passport.

“Omicron. Where exactly did you get these?”

He looked up from his comic. “I told you. From my colleagues. Does m’lady think I’m the only magical person around?”

Except for the road itself, there were no signs of human habitation. No fences. No telegraph polls. Just squat junipers, the rotten remains of pinyon trees, and bald patches of umber sand.

“How much farther?” asked Omicron.

“Don’t know. My GPS stopped working a half hour ago. But if I remember what it said… Should be coming up soon, on the right.”

They had left Santa Fe two hours earlier, driving first southwest, then northwest around the Jemez Mountains, and finally true west, away from the national monuments and wilderness study areas, away from the ranches and ghost towns, into the sandy epicenter of nowhere.

“I think that’s it,” said Riya, pointing ahead at a rusty postbox donning a faded painting of a black crow with a golden eye.

Riya turned the Titan into the driveway beside the postbox. The truck bounced along the weedy path and up a steep hill.

She stopped the truck at the top of the hill and gazed out at the remarkable landscape below. The driveway twisted down a slope on the other side to a flat expanse of tan desert. But in the center of the lifeless valley, beside a battered trailer, lay a fenced square of vibrantly green grass, like a shimmering cube of jade in a sandbox.

“Shall we?” said Omicron.

Riya accelerated down the hill, scaring off a roadrunner eating beetles at the edge of the driveway.

The trailer was fairly pitiful: windows cracked, front porch caving in on one corner, roof tiles mostly missing. There was an outbuilding filled with straw, a Jeep with the bonnet raised, and a shed with an anvil and furnace beside a tool shelf.

Riya parked the truck, slid down from the high seat, and walked automatically away from the ramshackle home toward the field of lovely green. It looked to be about two acres. Riya leaned against the fence.

“Omicron! Take a look at this!”

He joined her by the fence and they stared through its slats. A bison stood on the other side, munching grass, tail flicking away flies. Riya didn’t think she’d ever seen anything half so proud or beautiful. It looked almost as big as an elephant—a mass of wooly muscle, sharp horns, beating hooves, a great furry face more magnificent than a lion’s.

“You know,” Riya said quietly, “they used to stop the trains heading out west, let the passengers out to view the herds of bison. The men would bring out their rifles. They slaughtered these by the hundreds. Just for fun. Like a game.”

“I don’t like that story,” said Omicron.

“Yeah. I don’t like it either.”

The screen door on the trailer crashed open with a bang! Riya and Omicron started and spun as cowboy boots clicked across the porch and a voice rang out, “Get the hell away from him!”

Omicron smiled. “Hello there! Sorry to startle you. We were admiring this fine creature—”

“Get the hell away from Bill.”

“Of course. Of course.”

Omicron, Riya a step behind him, left the fence and walked back to the trailer.

“Who are you?” asked the woman on the porch.

Riya stared up at her. The woman was old—very old—with a face like cracked leather and two snowy braids that hung almost to her waist. She was dressed in faded denim and there was a tomahawk hooked to her belt, feathers and beads hanging from one end. She held a Winchester rifle—one of those lever-action carbines with an engraved iron frame like in western movies. The gun that won the west.

“I asked who you were,” the woman repeated, her golden eyes scanning both of them warily.

“I am called Omicron. This is Riya De Moor. We’ve come to help you.”

“How’d you find this place?”

He held up the page with the crayon writing. “Your niece.”

The woman sniffed. “She ain’t my niece, not really. They just call me Auntie.”

Omicron nodded. “I assumed as much.”

She lowered her rifle. “I’m Sable Crow,” she told them, flashing a half-hearted smile. Her teeth were very white, except for one incisor, which was gold. “You say you’re here to help me? Tell me, girlie, that truck of yours gassed up?”

“Yeah,” said Riya. “I got petrol in Torreon.”

“Good. My Jeep’s on the fritz. You drive.” She set her rifle’s barrel over a shoulder, reached into the trailer to retrieve a black fedora, which she tossed crookedly onto her head, and marched for the pickup truck.

“Okay. Er... Sure.” Riya walked to the driver’s side door, casting Omicron a puzzled look.

“Right to business,” said Omicron. “I like this old girl.”

Sable Crow set her rifle in the back of the truck and, with an energetic grunt, pulled herself up after it.

“What exactly are we doing?” asked Riya, climbing behind the wheel.

“Hunting,” said Sable. “Now drive.”

From where they were parked on a ridge about a mile from the trailer, Riya had a clear view of the valley and the distant mesas. She pulled compact binoculars from her rucksack and peered through the open driver’s side window.

“If you’re shooting for that coyote down on the left,” said Riya, “it’s a good five hundred yards. No way you make a shot like that without a scope. How long is your barrel? Twenty inches? That shot’s impossible.”

Sable lay in the back of the truck, one eye open along the barrel of her rifle. “I can make it. And I ain’t hunting the coyote. Something else is, and that’s what I’m shooting for.”

Riya scanned the area. “I don’t see any other predators.”

Omicron, settled in the passenger seat, nudged her elbow and pointed at the sky. Riya adjusted the focus on the binoculars.

“I only see… What is that? Almost looks like a drone.”
