A tiny silver triangle was hovering at an unknown distance, rocking slowly back and forth in the wind. As Riya watched, it dove like a missile toward the desert floor. She struggled to keep it in view as it struck the coyote in an explosion of sand.

“Whoa!” cried Riya. “That thing just obliterated the coyote! I can’t see—wait. There’s the coyote’s head. And I think that’s the hindquarters over there. And that might be a leg.”

In the Venn diagram vision of the binoculars, Riya watched a great crouched shape trample about the bloody remains, snapping up scraps of bone and meat in a sharp beak. It was a massive bird, or at least that’s what it most resembled. Its wingspan had to be at least fifteen feet.

“Looks like some hideous gargoyle statue,” Riya thought aloud.

“It’s an achiyalatopa,” explained Sable Crow. “A rockwing, a demon of the air. Its feathers are flint and its beak is obsidian.”

“And you can take it down with a firearm?” asked Omicron doubtfully.

“It’s got a weak point at the neck. Small target though,” said Sable, adjusting her aim.

Riya squinted through the binoculars as Sable fired. Crack! The huge bird twisted and fell into the sand. Riya smelled acrid gunpowder, heard Sable work the lever, saw the achiyalatopa writhe and straighten up onto its long legs. It beat its wings furiously, once, twice, three times. As the rifle boomed a second time in the back of the truck, the achiyalatopa took off in a rush of stone feathers and blown sand.

“Well shit. I gotta upgrade my bullets,” grunted Sable, sitting up. “Don’t just sit there, girlie! Get this truck moving! Now I’ve pissed it off.”

Riya threw down the binoculars and started the truck. The achiyalatopa circled once in the cloudless sky, then flew toward the ridge where they were parked.

“Giant demon bird, right,” muttered Riya, slamming the stick into reverse and revving the Titan backward at an angle, then forward as fast as it would go.

In the rearview mirror, through the murky curtain of dust thrown up by the truck, Riya saw the deadly shape of the achiyalatopa closing in. Sable’s rifle fired again.

“I can’t make a shot with us bouncing all over!” Sable shouted.

Riya didn’t answer. The ground was a mess of slick sand, sharp stone, and stunted junipers. She swerved this way and that, shocks straining, engine groaning. The land dead ahead was open and left them vulnerable to attack, so she turned right into a gorge between twenty-foot ledges.

Omicron was laughing and pulling on his gauntlet. “What a ride! Isn’t it, m’lady?”

“If you say so,” said Riya.

“We gotta problem!” called Sable. “I can’t see the rockwing!”

Riya twisted in her seat. The sky behind them was empty.

“Where—” she began, turning back to the steering wheel.

The monstrous bird was in front of them, stone talons extended. It slammed into the bonnet of the truck and smashed its head through the windscreen. Riya screamed and lost control of the steering wheel. The truck veered to the left, scraping along the rock ledge, filling the vehicle with sparks and flying gravel.

The achiyalatopa whipped its neck back and forth, its razor sharp beak snapping, trying to get ahold of Riya. Riya pressed her body back into the seat, her hand scrambling desperately in the rucksack behind her. As she reached for her pistol, Omicron pushed his way in front of her and punched the bird with his gauntleted fist. The bird was blasted off the bonnet in a shower of glass. It tumbled into the sand and lay quivering.

Riya swerved to a stop alongside the achiyalatopa. She exhaled, opened her door, and climbed out.

“Oh shit,” groaned Riya.

Sable hopped from the back of the truck. “Don’t worry. The rockwing can’t hurt you no more.”

“It’s not that. This truck is a bloody rental!”

Omicron climbed down from the far side of the truck and joined them as they approached the achiyalatopa. The bird lay on its back, twitching and kicking. Sable pulled the tomahawk from her belt. It was a beautiful weapon with a dark wood handle and the bowl of a smoking pipe on the back side of the blade.

Sable brought the tomahawk down between the bird’s eyes. It sunk as if into flesh, but when she pulled it free and the achiyalatopa collapsed, the body seemed to transform into a pile of gray stones—flint feathers, a lumpy boulder head, two sharp rocks where the beak had been.

“You think there are more of these things?” asked Riya.

“This is the third I’ve seen,” said Sable bitterly, “this week.”

“Then we’ve got our work cut out for us,” said Omicron.

“Let’s get back to the trailer. I’ll make some supper,” said Sable, hooking the tomahawk back onto her belt.

“Thanks for dinner,” said Riya, squeezing past Sable in her threadbare armchair and setting the dirty dishes in the trailer’s sink.

Sable lifted a beaded purse from the floor. She pulled a thick pinch of tobacco from the bag, tucked it into the silver bowl on her tomahawk, and lit the pipe with a match. The smoke burned Riya’s eyes and its earthy smell made her feel both sleepy and nauseous. She moved to where Omicron sat cross-legged on a loveseat, and scooting his knee aside, squeezed herself onto the cushion.

They sat for several minutes in smoky silence, Omicron examining one of the half-finished pieces of jewelry that lay about the trailer, Sable sucking on her pipe and blowing gray-blue rings, Riya watching the rings roll, stretch, fade, vanish.

“So I take it you’re the next resurrected warrior of old,” Riya finally said to Sable. Her voice sounded unnaturally loud and intrusive in the still room. “What—er—what tribe are you from?”

“No tribe. Or perhaps, all of them. My time marked the end of the One and the beginning of the Many.”

“I’m not sure I follow.”

Sable closed her eyes and inhaled deeply, the glow of the burning tobacco intensifying, then released two horns of gray smoke from her nostrils.

“I was born far from here and long ago, Miss Riya De Moor. Warrior? Yes, I was a warrior. But also more. I was the last great huntress and the first great queen of these lands.”

Riya sat up. “These lands? Do you mean the Americas?”

“That ain’t their true name, but yes. That was my life, my fate. And then I died a heroine’s death and they lay my body in the ground. My body was warm and dry and comfortable for many ages. And my soul… Oh my soul. My mind soared over a wide, bright country. But all that ended when the bomb went off on top of my corpse. I heard the boom. I felt a tug like gravity. I was rushed backward, and forward, and inward.”

“The energy of the Trinity blast brought you back to life?”

Sable’s tobacco had burned away. She sucked at the pipe with a little whistle, spit out a bit of leaf, nodded. “I ran from the blast site, across the desert. Found myself lost and alone in the center of a cattle ranch. Got a job with the ranch hands for a while. Then turned to blacksmithing. Bought this place. Just kinda trying to live, you know.”

“And how long ago was your previous life?” inquired Riya.

Omicron set aside the jewelry. “She is old, Riya. Very, very old. What you’d call paleoamerican. She walked the earth ten thousand years ago. Pre-Flood.”

Sable slapped the side of the tomahawk, emptying the bowl into a bucket that served as a garbage bin. “What would a European sorcerer from the Middle Ages know about the Flood?”

“Perhaps very little,” conceded Omicron, “if that’s truly all he was.”

Riya looked over at Omicron curiously, but already the conversation was moving in a direction all the more strange.

“I was so afraid when my eyes were forced opened,” Sable said quietly. “All that cruel light and harsh laughter. But when the atomic flames died away, I was just an old woman again.”

“So your powers did not awaken with your body?” asked Omicron.

Sable shook her head. “Not really. Nor in the decades since. Until…until quite recently.”

Omicron sat up straighter. “Explain.”

“Things are changing,” said Sable. “I first noticed it a month ago. Whispers in the dark. A blossoming energy in my bones, like in the old days. And then I saw the achiyalatopa. And worse.”

“I knew it,” breathed Omicron. “The dark influence of Arawn is emerging, even in this distant, dusty corner of the globe. And the might of Arianrhod.”

“Where do you think the achiya…achi…the rockwings are coming from?” asked Riya.

“I know where they’re coming from, girlie. See, I wasn’t alone when I woke. Something else was with me. It was weak, too. But now? Now it’s strong again. It’s using an old spell to make the achiyalatopa. Takes a basalt boulder, bathes it in cold water, roasts it in white flame. They become eggs. Rockwing eggs.” She looked at Riya. “Witchcraft, girlie.”

Riya had been tense and stiff, but now relaxed, the air leaking from her lungs in a relieved sigh. “That’s it? The monster we’re after is a witch? After a dragon that should be easy.”

Sable chuckled. “A dragon is a great dumb brute. A wanagi—dark spirit—it is…something else. Bad things happen around them. There are reports coming in. Park rangers claiming to see unnatural things in the desert. So no, this won’t be easy.”

“Oh.” Riya stood. The trailer was making her feel claustrophobic. “I think I need to stretch my legs.”

“Bill’ll be sleeping. Don’t bother him,” said Sable.

“Right.”

Riya grabbed her cane and exited the trailer. She limped off the porch and began pacing in the weedy driveway. The sky was pitch-black to the east and oily purple to the west. There was no wind, just the songs of insects and the constant glow of stars and moon.

What was happening back in St. Pyr right now? It would be early morning there. Her students would be home. They’d be waking up soon, showering, preparing breakfast, maybe even doing last minute homework to hand in to the supply teacher. Riya felt an impulsive urge to call Violet Connah and make sure she was coming to the cottage to feed Tom Bombadil, but a glance at her phone showed that there was no signal.

“What am I doing here?” she mused aloud.

Her thoughts began to pinball through the history of her life. She thought of her students, her cottage, her cat. The dragon buried in her garden. The landmine buried by the road in Iraq. Violet. Omicron. Sable Crow. Teaching history. Making history. Slaying monsters.

She drew a deep breath of desert air, stowed the phone in her pocket, and headed back inside.

She awoke to the sound of banging and for a terrifying second thought she was back in Iraq, but as she lay curled up on the loveseat in Sable’s trailer, Riya realized it was the sound of metal tools outside.

Sharp morning light burned her eyes as she walked onto the porch. Omicron was nowhere to be seen, but Sable was working at the blacksmith shed, sweat streaming off her ancient face and hardened arms.

“Morning!” Sable called, setting down her hammer. “Sleep okay?”

“Sure,” Riya lied, massaging her aching lower back with the knuckles of her right hand.

Riya approached the shed. Whatever Sable was working on, it wasn’t jewelry.

“Are you making a weapon?” Riya asked loudly as the hammering resumed.

“Yup. Omicron asked me to make it for him. Custom job. Guess he ain’t content with the weaponry of this century.”

Riya looked at the length of battered, hot-red metal Sable was pounding. It was a blade of some kind, short and heavy, and there were several others like it lying nearby. On a desk beside the anvil, she saw a mess of papers covered in Omicron’s handwriting with diagrams and measurements, many details scratched out and drawn multiple times.

“Will this weapon be used to kill the witch?” Riya asked.

Sable set the hammer aside, lifted up the blade with a pair of tongs, and engulfed it in a vat of steaming oil. The oil hissed.

“Doubt it,” said Sable. “But those might.”

She nodded at a shelf to Riya’s right. Riya turned and examined a line of golden cartridge cases standing like a row of soldiers.

“Your bullets are missing their bullets,” smirked Riya. “They’re just the rim and casing.”

“And pre-sealed with primer and powder. The bullet tips will be magical. In this case, blessed fire. Best way to take down a witch.”

“I can’t imagine Omicron using a gun.”

“I use the gun. He’ll use this.” She pointed at the short blades piling up.

“Where is he, anyway?”

Sable pointed a soot-blackened finger at the bison’s grassy paddock. “Bonding with Bill. Your magic colleague is a deer this morning.”

Riya grinned. “Nice way to start the day, I guess.”

The older woman approached the younger, wiping her hands on her jeans and staring curiously into Riya’s face.

“He’s more than he seems, you know,” said Sable.

“How do you mean?”

“I mean I’ve been living in this modern world for more than seventy years. It still feels off. I still feel out of place. But this Omicron? He is right at home. Acclimated. Assimilated.”

“Some people handle change better than others, I guess.”

Sable flashed her golden tooth. “It’s not just that. This ain’t his first rodeo.”

She went to stoke the furnace, leaving Riya to ponder her words.

They spent the whole of the next three days in Sable’s valley. The old woman pounded away with her hammer. The old man wandered in and out of the trailer, muttering and checking maps and ‘seeing’ with his gauntlet. Riya was positively bored. She gave her pistol a thorough cleaning, then did the same for Sable’s rifle. She made a food run to a rundown store on a Navajo service road in the town of Crownpoint. She watched Bill. She waited.

Sable and Omicron finally divulged their full plan to Riya one night as they sat around a campfire behind the trailer, eating cans of soup heated on the coals.

“A geologist went missing last week at Sheep Springs,” Sable said, scraping the last bit of chowder from her can. “And yesterday morning two brothers went hiking near White Rock and haven’t been seen since. It means she is feeding, and getting stronger each day. We have to act fast.”

“How do we find the witch?” asked Riya.

“There’s a pattern to her movements,” Omicron explained, laying out a crinkled map on the sand. “We think we know where she’ll be each night. The trouble is, this heinous spirit can sense Sable’s power, and mine too, probably, and she’ll flee if we come near. We’ll need someone non-magical to draw her in, keep her busy, and ideally, wound her. Then Sable can sweep in for the kill!”

Riya set down her supper. She thought she knew where this was going. “Uh-huh. And what will you be doing during all this, Omicron?”

“When the witch knows she’s under attack,” said Sable, “she’ll send for her minions to come to her aid. All the remaining achiyalatopas will come tearing down on us. Omicron will deal with them.”

The wizard beamed. “It’ll give me a chance to test out my new toy.”

A muscle twitched in Sable’s cheek. “It ain’t a damn toy.”

“So while Omicron takes out the rockwings, I’ll be the non-magical target, right?” Riya asked.

“If you don’t mind playing bait,” said Sable.

“I’m restless as hell. Doing anything sounds good to me.”

“Right ho!” clapped Omicron. “We strike tomorrow. We’ll drop off m’lady at the canyon where the witch is headed, and you’ll hike into place. Bring your gun, but don’t act conspicuously. You’re just another hiker on holiday. Eager, inattentive, delicious. Engage the witch when she accosts you and hold her off long enough for Sable to come in and finish it.”

“And Riya,” added Sable, “be on your guard, you hear. This foe can be deceptive. She’ll try to feed your fears, throw you off balance. Don’t let her. This ain’t gonna be no picnic in the park.”

As Riya hiked beside the winding roads of Chaco Culture National Historical Park, then up into the mesas, she leaned less on her cane than usual. Her back seemed to be doing better lately. She stared down past the crescent-shaped houses of the ancient Chacoans, past the clicking cameras of tourists, into the xeric scrubland, the canyon bright with blue sagebrush, pale cactus, sunburned stone—a land fit for jackrabbits, pronghorns, rattlesnakes, and myths.

The brochure in Riya’s rucksack explained that Chaco Canyon had been a major center of trade and culture for centuries, long before European settlers arrived. The sandstone structures had been the largest ever built in North America until the 1800s. The history teacher in her drank in the sights, but the soldier stayed on guard, ready for action.

When the sun went down, an elderly park ranger with a name tag sporting “NEZ” told Riya and the other straggling hikers that the park would soon be closing. Riya slipped away into the shadows of some boulders, hiding herself between a tangle of windblown tumbleweeds and a great chunk of tan stone, its surface decorated with ancient petroglyphs: a dagger moon, a left handprint, a shining star.

When the noises of the park visitors and rangers faded, she crept out from her hiding and wandered around the largest of the ruins. Pueblo Bonito, it was called, beautiful town. Riya thought the name was insufficient on every level.

The ruined Great House was a massive D-shaped structure of red and yellow bricks. It had originally boasted over eight hundred rooms and their skeletal remains stood in a labyrinth of square doorways, T-shaped windows, and tiny rooms open-roofed to the stars.

The sky darkened. Even the insects were staying silent.

Riya shifted her rucksack onto one shoulder so that she could slide a hand inside and grip the handle of her pistol. She kept thinking she saw shapes in the dimness—here a crouching body, there a writhing snake. A coldness was creeping into the canyon, permeating the stones, closing in on the last quarter moon.

“Hello?” came a faint voice.

Riya started, her breath catching in her throat. She tightened her grip on the gun.

“Hello?” the voice called again, an elderly man’s voice, trembling, coming from somewhere in the ruins. “Is anybody out there? Please. I think I’m lost!”

Riya clasped her eyes shut, exhaled through puckered lips, tried to slow the mad thumping in her chest.

“It’s not real,” she told herself in a whisper.

“Please? I don’t know what’s happening!”

Riya drew out the gun and let her bag fall to the ground.

The voice grew more desperate. “Someone’s in here with me! I don’t like her. I think she’s gonna hurt me. Please!”

Riya cursed under her breath, trying desperately to remember whether she had seen anyone very old touring the park. The one park ranger was elderly, but surely his colleagues would have told her if he or anyone else had gone missing, wouldn’t they? Someone would be looking. It didn’t make sense.

“Oh no!” croaked the voice. “Ouch! No, don’t do that! That hurts! Please!”

Riya grunted and ducked into the ruins, pistol in her right hand, cane stiff in her left, limping into the gloom.

She knew it was a trap. She knew what was waiting for her inside, but the tremulous old voice was crying. Great sobs in the dark, hollow and hopeless.

“Where are you?” Riya called out.

There was no answer. She moved into the next tiny chamber, then the next, scraping her shoulder against the door frames. Her foot hit a step in the dark and she fell, her cane clattering onto rock.

A howl of anguish echoed through the maze, now more animal than human. Riya pulled herself to her feet, holding out the pistol in both hands. She turned to go back the way she had come, but clouds had blotted out both moon and stars. She reached out in the dark, groping along the sandstone bricks.

A square room.

A long chamber.

And she was out, not in open desert, but a courtyard in the center of the great ruin. She squinted through the dimness. She saw the silhouette edges of broken walls, some scattered bristly shrubs, and a deep circle dug into the earth: a kiva, a Native worshipping chamber.

The screaming ceased. The man’s voice was no more, but there was another sound in the night air: a sound of battle.

Riya spun and stared up at the crest of a nearby mesa. She could just make out the silhouetted shape of Omicron against the gray clouds, moving this way and that. A strange weapon was in his hand, like something between a sword and a whip, bending, stabbing, slicing, illuminated by its own magical blue light. Sable’s weapon, enhanced by the gauntlet. She saw the shapes of the mighty achiyalatopas struggling with the wizard, their winged bodies reduced to scattered stones with each magical attack.

“One less thing to worry about,” thought Riya, but the words brought her no comfort. The air had gone deathly cold.

Riya spun, gasped, fired her gun into the night.

A woman stood in front of her, mere inches away, lank black hair falling over emaciated shoulders all the way to the sand at her feet. Her eyes were chips of ice, her mouth a wicked slash of broken teeth, her body naked, gaunt, almost skeletal.

The bullet flew, but the witch did not move. Instead, a wisp of black smoke slithered from where the bullet hole should have been.

A scrape to her right. Riya twisted, fired again.

Another witch, the mirror image of the first, walked toward her across the courtyard, hands extended, thin black tongue licking thin black lips.

Riya fired again, then again, ears ringing, bullets whistling through the ghostly form to crunch into the walls behind her.

Another witch on her left, two more behind her. There were witches in the ruined windows and balanced on the jagged walls. Skinny bodies, dragging wet hair across sand and stone, their breath like the panting of dogs.

Palm sweaty over the grip of her gun, Riya spun in place. Her gaze snapped from one hideous body to the next. One had to be real, the rest, projections. She searched for a sign of trueness, the outlier, the one true monster.

“Where the hell is Sable?” Riya hissed through clenched teeth.

A witch leaped forward, bending near the ground as it slipped past Riya’s knees like a wind. She fired at it and the bullet sprayed sand into her face. Another witch swept behind her and this time Riya felt broken fingernails scraping across her legs. She twisted, losing her balance and shooting into the air.

They closed in, inching nearer with lumbering, silent steps.

Riya’s finger flexed but the pistol’s slide locked back into place; she was out of ammo. She punched out with the gun, swinging wildly, meeting cold emptiness with each strike.

Then she was lost in a swirling tangle of black hair, groping fingers, icy gazes. They would hold her down, eat her eyes, chew on her bones until nothing was left.

Riya shut her eyes, waiting for death.

The ground trembled. The witches fell back, startled and shrieking. Riya kneeled in the sand and turned her head to watch as a huge shape leaped over a broken wall and galloped toward her.

It was a colossal bison, hooves beating the ground, horns dipped and eyes glistening. Upon its back, without saddle or reins, sat Sable Crow, her snowy braids bouncing on her shoulders, her Winchester raised in her hands. She fired as she rode, the rifle’s sparks lighting up the ruins all around.

One of the witches to Riya’s right shrieked and stumbled. At once, each of the other ghostly bodies vanished into black haze. Sable fired again, the bullet punching through the true witch’s protruding ribs. The witch groaned and hobbled backward toward the open kiva. As the bison galloped forward, Sable tossed her rifle to Riya and drew her silver tomahawk. The bison reached the witch and Sable swung her tomahawk into the witch’s face. The witch screamed and fell backward into the kiva, her body hitting the ground twelve feet below with a thud.

Shaking, Riya pulled herself to her feet, rifle in hand, and walked toward the towering bison and its majestic rider. Sable leaned forward, patting her mount’s furry neck. Below her, the thin form of the witch writhed in the shadows, cursing in a language Riya did not know or care to ever hear again.

“How did you know which one was the true witch?” Riya asked Sable.

Sable swept aside one of her braids and wiped her face. A drop of black blood had splashed onto her left cheek. “When you’ve shared a womb with someone, you don’t easily forget them.” She pulled something from a shirt pocket. “Here, girlie! You finish it.”

She flicked a tiny, glowing object to Riya, who caught it. It was one of the golden cartridges Sable made, and it was tipped with a spike of radiant orange, like fire frozen in time.

Riya pushed the magical bullet into the rifle’s loading gate, pumped the lever, and raised the gun. She fired into the kiva and a brilliant vortex of flame bloomed in the night, issuing the hideous scream of the damned. And something else.

“Oh my god! Did you see that?” Riya asked, clutching at her chest. “The witch changed! Right when the bullet struck! She looked different. Like an old man. An old man screaming. Sable?”

Sable didn’t answer at first. She was staring across the landscape.

“The spirit needed a body to possess. It took one when it first awoke.”

Riya’s blood went cold. She gazed into the kiva. It was empty but for threads of snaking smoke. “So I just… Sable, did I just…? Why didn’t you tell me it was possessing another’s body? Why! I should have known. I would have...”

“Would have what? You did nothing wrong. You saved him. You set him free.”

“I shot him!”

“You did what you had to do. What, you still thinking this is all some grand adventure with a happy ending? All stories end in death, Riya De Moor. Best you remember that.”

Riya turned away from the kiva, eyes wet. Furious, confused, terrified. She retrieved her cane, feeling along the floor in the Great House, then joined Sable. Leaving the ruins to meet up with Omicron, they all departed the canyon without another word.

Riya packed the last of her things and loaded the bag into the back of the battered Titan. Omicron had magically repaired the windscreen, but the truck still looked like it had aged a decade in the six days Riya had driven it.

A light rain was falling, turning the sand red. Omicron stood on the trailer’s porch, arms crossed, smiling at Riya.

“M’lady did well last night.”

“I’m just glad it’s done. And a bit desperate to get back in my classroom, where battles exist only in books. You sure you want to stay here?”

“For a few days, aye. I have research to do with Lady Crow. Amongst other things, we have an idea of how to magically treat that spinal injury of yours.”

“I wouldn’t say no to that.” She took a step toward him, and her worry must have shown on her face. Omicron’s expression turned serious and he walked down the steps to join her.

“Is something wrong?” he asked.

“It’s just… Sable told me something about the witch. She said it was her twin sister. At least I think that’s what she meant. She said something about sharing a womb with the monster.”

“Hm. Perhaps they were twins. Or perhaps Lady Crow was merely referring to time spent with the wanagi in Death. Or maybe she meant that creature was once some other part of herself. I do not know, m’lady, and I doubt if she will ever divulge the whole truth. That’s often how it was in the old days, in the deep past. Beauties beyond comprehension. Terrors no mortal could face. Mysteries best left alone.”

“I don’t like mysteries I can’t solve.” She scanned Omicron’s wrinkled face, his mismatched eyes, his cryptic smile. “She also said that you are more than you say, that your past is more complicated. Is that true?”

“Isn’t everyone’s past complex?”

“That’s not what I mean, Omicron. If I’m going to do this with you, I want the truth. Were you born in the Middle Ages? Was Merlin the first name given to you or were there others, and other lives, in the deep past?”

He stroked his beard. “Hm. Well. There were other names, aye. Other times. Other ages.”

“Then who are you, really?”

He looked at her then, a pained expression on his ancient face. “I…am Omicron, of course!” He laughed but there was no music in the sound.

“So you won’t tell me more?”

“Not...yet. Does that make it impossible for you to fight by my side?”

She considered, stabbing her cane into the sand. “If anything made me walk away, it would be what I saw last night. What I did last night. But no. I can’t quit now. If I quit fighting, I’d always wonder what tragedies happened because I wasn’t there to try and stop them. So...so I’m with you, Omicron Wonderbuck, or whatever your true name is.”

“Splendid! Then you’d best be on your way for now. Don’t want to miss that flight! Say hello to Lady Violet for me. I’ll see you soon.”

“When is soon?”

“When I need your help again. Maybe a week. Maybe a month. Only the gods know for sure, and maybe not even them.”

She pulled herself into the driver’s seat, wincing as she adjusted her sore back. “Cheers.”

“Goddess speed, m’lady.”

Riya drove south along the nameless road, through gentle rains and blue mists, past mountains, mesas, jagged gorges, back to Albuquerque.

The soldier standing guard inside the interrogation room was almost seven feet tall, a camo-clad statue of muscle with a square chin and bored, beady eyes—the typecast henchman. The MP-443 Grach pistol at his side looked comically small against his bulk. No doubt he had been chosen for the post because of his cinematic look.

Riya adjusted her sore wrists in the handcuffs connected to the metal chair. She wanted to lean forward onto the table in the center of the cell and take a nap but the handcuffs prevented it. More than anything, she wanted a shower. There was still blood in her hair, blood soaked into her skin, blood under her fingernails.

She heard footsteps from the hall and voices bickering in Russian. The door swung inward, startling the guard, who jumped to attention and saluted with such bravado that he smacked himself in the face. A lone man entered and shut the door behind him. Without a word, the man sat stiffly in a chair across from Riya, clicked open the briefcase he was carrying, and began pulling manila envelopes out one at a time and setting them with OCD-precision along the edge of the table. When the last envelope was in place, he snapped the briefcase shut, set it on the floor beside his chair, and opening up the first envelope, began to silently read from a stapled stack of papers.

Riya exhaled, perhaps louder than was necessary, and examined the newcomer to pass the time. The man couldn’t have looked more unlike the burly guard. He was short, gaunt, liver-spotted and sharp-eyed, with a gray goatee that traced his thin lips and weak chin. Clearly a career military man, but whereas the soldier by the door had spent his time at the gym and shooting range, this older man was used to sitting behind desks, reading classified briefings, and making dangerous phone calls.

After ten minutes of scanning documents and flipping pages, the man cleared his throat—dislodging a large amount of phlegm, which he swallowed surreptitiously—and turned back to the first page. He began to read aloud, enunciating each word in very good English, though with a distinct western Russian accent.

“Riya De Moor. Born in St. Thomas Hospital, London, on the twenty-ninth of July, 1983… Oh my!” He looked up from the page at Riya. “What are the chances? Today is your birthday, isn’t it?”

“Happy birthday to me,” she said.

“I am afraid the kitchen in this prison is hardly suited for baking, otherwise I might order a cake be made in your honor.”

“It’s the thought that counts,” said Riya, baring her teeth in a mock smile.

The man cleared his throat again and cast his gaze back onto the page.

“Riya De Moor,” he repeated. “Born in St. Thomas Hospital, London, on the twenty-ninth of July, 1983. Father: Johannes De Moor. Dutch. An architect. Mother: Faiza Khurmi De Moor. Indian. Formerly a professor of cognitive neuroscience at Imperial College. Currently…unemployed. And you have a younger sister. Savi. Is that all correct?”

“You forgot about the family dog,” said Riya. “Nanak. He was a German Shepherd.”

He turned the page, carefully creasing the folded corner between thumb and forefinger. Riya decided he definitely had OCD.

“According to our records,” he continued, “you graduated from University College London in 2005, but rather than using your history degree, you joined the Royal Military Police. Curious. Was it an exciting career?”

Riya shrugged. “Not really. Mostly I assisted civilian police forces. Basic crime reduction duties. Lots of paperwork.”

“Is that why you volunteered to go to Iraq during Operation Telic in 2007? I see here that you were attached to the Royal Marines. Command 44. You had four confirmed kills. But on your second tour you were injured.”

“Wow,” said Riya dryly. “Your Russian intelligence officers are really something. They’ve learned how to use Google.”

He set down the papers and stared at her. “I want to know what you did next. You see, in my report it says you retired from the military and settled in Wales to—” he double-checked the paper, “—teach school children.”

“That about sums it up.”

“But…you never left the military, did you, Lance Corporal De Moor? Or if you did, it was to join a separate branch of the British government. Secret Intelligence Service?”

“You think I’m MI6?”

“I think you are more than a schoolteacher. After all, why would a schoolteacher crash a speedboat into the Russian coast outside of my city earlier this morning? Why would she be racing across the Black Sea last night, pursued by the Turkish military?”

Riya flexed her lips and blew a puff of air up at her fringe, knocking it sideways to alleviate an itch. “Hm. Yeah, when you put it that way…”

He placed his hands—skinny fingers like a pale spider, perfectly manicured nails—on the tabletop and leaned toward her.

“Why were you in Turkey?”

“Holiday.”

“Tell me, De Moor! It will be easier for you this way. There are other interrogators besides me in this prison. They have other methods than I do. Less pleasant methods.”

Riya adjusted herself in the chair, her handcuffs jingling. “What time is it?”

“Don’t change the subject. We—”

“The time! What is it?”

His face flashed annoyance. “What does that have to do with… Ten in the morning!”

Riya nodded, calculating hours in her mind, estimating flight durations, trying to remember the closest major airport to Tuapse, Russia.

“Ten? Okay then,” she said. “Guess I’ve got time. Why not? Frankly, it’s a helluva story. It might be fun to tell someone.”

The interrogator scratched his goatee with a manicured nail. “I am glad you will cooperate. Much easier this way. So, in your own words. What happened? Why are you here?”

Riya made sure her expression remained confident while she collected herself. Her police and military training had kept her fear and stress in check during the day’s events, but to keep her imprisoners distracted until she was rescued, she would need to call on another type of training. As a history teacher, Riya had learned to take even the most mundane of past events and turn them into compelling stories for her students, and lucky for her, the story she had to tell now was anything but mundane.

She grinned. “It all started with a man who calls himself Omicron, a monster from ancient legend, and the burial mound of Achilles: hero of the Trojan War, who died, was burned and buried, and rose again…last week…outside the Turkish village of Erklik…”

Four days earlier…

“Damnation!” cursed Omicron, stamping a foot.

“You know, you really shouldn’t wear socks with sandals,” said Riya. “It’s sort of an unwritten rule.”

“‘Tis not the time for jests, m’lady!”

The wizard and the schoolteacher stood atop a grassy hill, their backs to the vast, stepped landscape of eastern Turkey—bone-white rock, milky skies, undulating hills of gold and green. At their feet lay a mound of freshly-turned earth. Clumps of soil, mingled with what looked like dried blood, led down the slope in front of them toward a coniferous woodland. Riya squinted at the shadowy edge of that forest, then turned to survey their lonely surroundings. To the north, the sun shone on the terracotta roofs of the little village of Erklik.

“It must have been frightening for him, waking up out here, alone,” said Riya.

“We should have been here! ‘Tis your fault we were late!”

“Come off it, Omicron! How do you figure that?”

“Because if we hadn’t made that pit stop in the Himalayas—”

“That was your idea. You said, to celebrate the end of school term, you’d take me on a holiday to that mythic spring!”

“Aye, but only to try and magically cure your ruddy back.”

“And I appreciate that,” said Riya, flexing her torso from side to side, keenly aware of the improvement the magical steamy pool had rendered several days earlier, “but you can’t blame me for the fact that we showed up here late.”

“Hm. Well. Perhaps. Though it still feels preferable to blaming myself.”

Riya rolled her eyes. She knelt and examined the ground.

“Crazy to think he was really here,” she mused. “The godlike Achilles, digging his way up from the grave.”

“Oh, he was here, alright, for almost thirty-two-hundred years! And we missed his awakening by what? Two days perhaps! ‘Twas our duty to be here. My duty.”

“No reason to mope,” said Riya, standing. “We can follow his trail through those woods, though isn’t that the area the villagers told us to avoid?”

“They say it hasn’t been safe for months.”

“And you believe them? You really think some cultish terrorist group is operating here, completely off the international radar? This Demir Dua organization sounds more like a local legend.”

Though Omicron’s expression remained angry, his lips twitched a smile. “M’lady has no trouble believing a legendary hero from the Trojan War woke up from death, but the possibility of a terrorist training camp in a Turkish forest is, what, too much to fathom?”

Riya jabbed him in the shoulder. “Come on. Let’s find this guy before it gets dark.”

Omicron pulled on the Gauntlet of Camelot. “We must advance with caution. I sense a great dread in that forest. An old evil, and a new one.”

They moved down the hill, Riya with one hand hovering over the holstered grip of her pistol, Omicron occasionally closing his eyes and reaching out with his gauntleted hand.

Riya found herself wishing Sable Crow was with them as they moved into the forest. Sable could track better than any human alive, or so she bragged. But the ancient gunslinger was apparently trekking through the Amazon in search of sacred materials to use in her magic bullets. Omicron had told Sable of their destination and was hopeful she would join them in four or five days time. For now, it was just Riya and the wizard against who-knows-what.

After wandering for twenty minutes through the maze of lofty trees, the trail they were following forked in two. Omicron took the left, instructing Riya to go right. She did so without a quarrel, although the woods made her uneasy. They were too quiet, the trees too still, without any sign of beast or bird or insect.

“Lovely summer holiday, this,” she grumbled to herself, ducking below the spiky boughs of a bent tree.

She came upon a path in the woods. Tire tracks were visible in streaks of dried mud. Riya had no sooner stepped onto the path when she heard the sound of an engine growing louder. She sprinted back into the brush, but a motorbike—old and rusty and issuing acrid smoke—had already appeared around a corner in the path.

Riya’s hand darted to the P226 at her side. She drew out the pistol and yanked back the slide.

The driver of the motorbike stared at her, slowing, then stopping. He was about Riya’s age, bearded, with dark eyes and a sweeping scar from one ear to the other, like a throat-cutting gone wrong, like a monstrous smile. An AK-47 hung at his side.

“Shit,” Riya hissed, raising her pistol. She felt no desire whatsoever to shoot this man. She wanted him to turn on his motorbike, drive off into the woods, and leave her be.

His eyes—coldly curious, hungry—scanned her where she stood beside the path.

“I’m just here to look for someone,” Riya told him, her voice calm. “Nobody needs to get hurt. Do you understand English?”

He licked his lips, slid off the motorbike, took a step toward Riya. His eyes locked with hers, and she hated what she saw in them. Riya’s finger tightened on the trigger.

A spear sunk into the man’s chest. Blood splattered the pine trees and the motorbike. The body fell in a heap on the path. Dead.

Riya gasped. She turned on her heel, aiming in the direction from where the spear had flown.

“Omicron? Is that…?”

She could see no one with her in the woods. Turning back to the dead terrorist, she noted that the spear pinning him to the earth was a simple tree branch stripped of bark with its tip whittled to deadly perfection.

“Who would...?”

She tilted her head back to look into the forest canopy. And there he was.

Achilles was seated in the crook of a tree, as still and silent as a statue. His body blended into the browns and reds of the foliage. Had it not been for the brilliant whites of his eyes, Riya might not have seen him at all, not even at second glance.

What had Riya expected him to look like? She couldn’t remember. But it couldn’t have been this. Achilles was tall, muscular, brown as the earth. His whole body was covered in burns: a quilt of scar tissue, wrinkled and blackened. His left leg ended at the calf. He sat poised as a cat, noble as a stallion, seeming to radiate power that made the hair on Riya’s neck stand on end.

In the prison, the interrogator tapped his fingers irritably on the table.

“Really, De Moor? A wizard and an ancient warrior? Do you take me for the sort of person who enjoys having their time wasted?”

“It’s the truth,” said Riya, adjusting her wrists in the handcuffs. “Whether or not you believe it is up to you. Now then, shall I continue?”

The interrogator opened his mouth to protest but the guard by the door blurted out, “Why was Achilles burned?” in a strong Russian accent.

Riya smirked. “Achilles died when he was shot through the ankle with a poisoned arrow. They burned his body on a ceremonial pyre and buried him beneath a great mound. Only they didn’t understand who he really was—what he really was.”

“And that is what?” asked the guard.

“The son of a goddess.”

The interrogator moaned and massaged his forehead with the fingers of his right hand.

“As an infant,” Riya explained to the guard, “Achilles’ mother, Nereid Thetis, dipped him into the sacred river Styx while holding him by the ankle. His skin was given magical protection, all except his left ankle and foot. When Paris’ arrow found its mark, Achilles was defeated, but fire could not entirely consume his demigod body. The ankle and foot rotted away with time but the rest of his flesh remained, entombed, until the goddess Arianrhod sent his spirit back to this world, last week.”

“Wow,” said the guard, nodding his approval. “Pretty cool.”

“Oh shut up, Egor,” said the interrogator.

“You don’t find it interesting?” asked Riya.

“Certainly not! Though…I am curious about this terrorist you met in the woods. He was Turkish?”

“Dunno. The villagers said the terrorists came from all sorts of places. The Middle East. Europe. Russia.”

“And you believed these villagers?”

“It wasn’t just them. Achilles had been hiding in those woods for two days before Omicron and I arrived, watching the Demir Dua, or Iron Prayer, as the terrorist organization’s name translates. He had learned a lot, including information imperative to our mission in Turkey.”

“I thought you and the wizard came to find Achilles,” said Egor.

“We did,” said Riya. “But we also came to find, and to kill, something else.”

Three days earlier…

Riya and Omicron had rented a sparsely furnished flat on the second floor of a building on the edge of Erklik. It was the only posted rental in the town, and though the online pics had been misleading and the rooms smelled of rot and cigarettes, Riya was relieved to stay safely inside four walls the day after their misadventure in the woods.

Achilles, now dressed in clothes Riya purchased in town, sat hunched on a stool by the kitchen window. Riya watched him from the kitchen doorway. He didn’t seem to move at all. Not to scratch an itch. Not to sigh. Not even to breathe. It was as if the spirit inside that huge, scarred form had not yet fully latched onto the physical body.

“You hungry yet?” she asked him.

“Hunger. Thirst. Exhaustion. What are these?”

His voice was a beautiful growl, dangerous and deep. He had not spoken for the first ten hours after Riya found him in the forest, but when he finally did, it was in perfect English. A panglot, like Omicron. Taught the First Words by his mother.

“You don’t like being back, do you?” asked Riya.

“I am back. And the fates care not for men’s desires. We are always at their will. That is the price.”

“Of what? The life of a warrior?”

“Of existence.” He moved to rub at the stump of his left leg. The movement was stiff, awkward, automaton-esque. “I do not like being back, Riya De Moor. Not like this. Not broken. Not ruined.”

“Omicron can help you. He helped me. I could barely walk without a cane until a week ago.”

“A cane? Look at me! I am shattered. Little more than a corpse. Some men live in their hearts. Some men live in their minds. I lived in my body, in this body, before... I am back, but I am not truly alive.”

They heard the toilet flush and Omicron entered from the hall, whistling and adjusting his belt.

“Oh quit being dramatic, Achilles!” called the wizard, sweeping into the kitchen. “You heard the lady. I’ll help you regain your former strength.”

“I cannot fight. I cannot run!”

“And you look like beef jerky, but that’s hardly the point.” Omicron opened the fridge, surveyed its bare interior, and shut it irritably. “From what you told me you saw in those woods, we three have plans to make, and fast. Lady Riya and I were too late to greet you upon resurrection, and for that I am sorry, but we may not be too late to deal with the next of Arawn’s monsters.”

“Where do we start looking for it?” asked Riya.

“No need, m’lady. We know where it is. Achilles sensed the beast’s presence in the woods. He has a keen nose for dread and divine mischief.”

“The monster’s already awake? It’s in the forest?” asked Riya, mentally picturing the terrorist on the motorbike, his scarred neck, his icy eyes. “Could it be that…that the terrorist organization is the monster?”

Omicron shook his head. “A poetic theory, but nay. Arawn is not a master of subtlety. This is a beast of tooth and horn and claw. But though Iron Prayer is not the monster, they do have the monster. Achilles told me he could hear it crying out the night before last, from the heart of the terrorists’ compound. They must have discovered and captured it before we got here.”

“No!” gasped Riya. “Quite the coincidence.”

Achilles crossed his long, scarred arms and shook his head. “Coincidence is a fool’s word.”

Omicron nodded. “There is dark magic at work in this place, m’lady. Arawn’s vile power infected the earth to awaken monsters, but that same power has leaked into the atmosphere. I have felt it since we first arrived. No doubt it has called these wretched men here from around the globe. Whether Arawn intended his beast to fall into Iron Prayer’s hands or not, I am sure it is an outcome he would heartily approve of.”

“They could release it in a populated area. Helluva terrorist attack,” mused Riya. “But for now, surely it’ll be as dangerous to them as it would be to us.”

“Not yet.” Achilles shifted on his stool as if to stand, then, remembering that his left foot was no more, slouched back against the window. “The beast you seek is a creature most rare. I have never seen one alive, thank fate, but I have seen the ribcage of one, many stars ago.”

Riya looked from Achilles to Omicron and back again, waiting for the reveal. They had defeated a dragon and killed a witch. Whatever this new adversary was, they must be able to handle it. But then why did she feel so cold, so small, so defenseless when Achilles said, “Typhon. We are hunting a typhon.”

It took Riya several seconds to think of how to respond. “Okay. But isn’t that like a world eater? A creature as big as a mountain? The locals would have noticed it by now. And how could a handful of terrorists capture something like that?”

“Typhons start out small,” said Omicron. “No bigger than a chicken egg, if the fairytales hold true, and they usually do, more or less. But ‘tis said they grow fast.”

“The skeletal remains I saw in my youth,” explained Achilles, “were from a typhon slaughtered at only a few years old. They were…large.”

“How large?” asked Riya.

“Large enough to be mistaken for a chain of islands. Several cities had been built upon the bones. Great temples. Public houses. Taverns. All stacked up on the mossy corpse of a typhon.”

“Charming image,” said Riya. “But I can’t imagine a terrorist start-up, no matter how well funded, being able to house and feed a mythical creature like this. Maybe it’ll starve? That would save us some trouble.”

Omicron found a package of dried noodles in a dusty cabinet and set a pot to boil. “Typhons feed on pain, m’lady. They flourish on a diet of violence and fear. You know how a decapitated hydra will simply grow a new head? A typhon is a bit like that, only exponentially more dangerous. Any attack—be it spear or bullet or nuclear blast—will only serve to make a typhon tougher, larger, deadlier. The more you fight it, the more you strengthen it.”

“Fan-damn-tastic,” said Riya. “So we have to annihilate the thing without hurting it? How is that supposed to work? Achilles, do you know how the dead typhon you saw was defeated?”

“Poisoned, I believe.”

Omicron splashed the noodles into the boiling water. “Well there we go! The beast’s insides are vulnerable.”

“But that hardly helps us,” said Riya. “It’s locked up in a terrorist compound. What are we to do? Storm the place? Just the three of us?”

Omicron retrieved a bowl and spoon, looking thoughtful. “We’d need more firepower for that. But aye. We don’t have time to wait for Lady Crow. And this will not be the simple monster hunt of our previous missions. This will be a modern battle against heavily-armed soldiers. Prepare yourself for that, m’lady. But first, I want to infiltrate this camp of theirs. Demir Dua intrigues me. I think I’ll don a buckish guise and return to the woods after my meal. See what I can find.”

“And what should we be doing?” asked Riya, worried her role would be to sit and wait as it had been during much of their time in New Mexico.

“Achilles must rest. And eat. You won’t be half as surly with a full belly, my new friend. Riya, perhaps you could work on acquiring a stash of weapons worthy of storming the compound.”

“And how am I supposed to do that?” asked Riya. “Erklik has a couple restaurants, so fattening up Achilles is easy enough, but I doubt they’re hosting any major gun shows.”

“Use your contacts,” said Omicron. “You must have peers from your days as a soldier you can call.”

“Nope.”

The wizard strained his pasta and gave Riya a doubtful glance through the rising steam.

“Well, maybe one,” Riya admitted. “But I am not calling him.”

“Oh, of course you are, m’lady!” beamed Omicron, slurping up a hot noodle and leaving flecks of water in his beard.

Two additional soldiers had joined burly Egor by the interrogation cell’s door. The three men stood huddled and looking at Riya, taking in each word of her tale. She had stopped addressing the interrogator directly except for occasional glances. The soldiers were a much more keen audience.

“So you had to get weapons?” asked Egor. “For the wizard and the Greek?”

“I got guns for me, mostly,” said Riya. “At the time I didn’t think about weaponry for Achilles. And Omicron fights with a combination of his sorcery, a unique weapon made for him by Sable Crow, and a magical gauntlet.”

The soldiers nodded and ooh!ed appreciatively.

“Where did you get your weapons?” asked Egor.

“I made a call to someone I knew from back in Iraq when I fought alongside the Royal Marines. Someone I had thought and hoped I would never have to see again.”

Two days earlier…

Omicron still hadn’t returned from his reconnaissance mission in the woods the next afternoon, as Riya stood alone in a field outside Erklik. The atmosphere was alive with a sharp breeze, a cool blue light, insect calls. She could see the distant line of trees where the wizard had no doubt infiltrated the terrorist compound. Concerned as she was for his safety, most of Riya’s energy was devoted to stressing about the upcoming meeting.

She spotted the plane approaching from the southeast. It landed on the flat stretch of wild grass, crunching to a stop just in front of Riya. She stared up at the private jet and sighed. The door swung open, a steep set of stairs descended, and a man about Riya’s age came skipping down, two steps at a time. He pushed his sunglasses up to settle into his greased hair, and rolling up his silk sleeves, gave Riya a tactless look over.

“Well, well. Look at you, doll! You’re really here. And looking a-okay. Gotta say, you were the last sucker in the unit I ever thought I’d see again. Somebody said you’d retired or some shit. Teaching school from a wheelchair or something.”

“Good afternoon, Bonneville. I assume you have what I asked for?” she said curtly.

“Now, now. None of this Bonneville bull. You call me Staff Sergeant Jameson Bonneville. Hah! Just kidding you, doll. Just call me Jock. Neither of us wear the uniform anymore.”

“My uniform is back at home in Wales, medals and all,” said Riya. “Where’s yours? Oh wait, when a soldier is court-martialed and dishonorably discharged, they probably take back the uniform, don’t they?”

Jock’s slick smile flattened out. “Whoa, sweetheart. Retirement hasn’t made you any more charming, has it? You always were a bit of a—”

“Do you have my weapons or not?”

“Yeah, yeah. I got it all. I thought it was a prank when you called me yesterday. Riya De Moor here. Could you bring a couple of crates of killing machines over to Middle-of-Nowhere, Turkey, ASAP? But here I am, as promised, and how do you greet me? Judgment! Sure I got caught selling weapons in a less than legal manner, but guess what, Lance Corporal Doll, today, you’re the one buying my products! A royal pain in the arse, and a hypocrite.”

“I have my reasons, Jock. Just unload the gear and be on your way.”

“Gladly.” He walked to the back of the jet and, with the assistance of the pilot, set two crates onto the grass, opening them with a flick of the hand and a salesman’s toothy grin. “Boo ya! One bloody beautiful L96 sniper rifle with adjustable bipod and static iron sights. You can take out a target from over a thousand meters with this. Two Gen 4 Glock 17 9mm pistols with 17-round magazines. Two SA80 A2 assault rifles. Then all the ammo a growing girl could ask for. And last but not least, your L109s. Lotta bang for your buck with these grenades. Literally! Whatcha planning on doing with all this? You know what, scratch that. I don’t wanna know! Ignorance is bliss. That’s Jock Bonneville’s motto. No questions asked. Everybody’s happy.”

“Yes. I’m positively giddy. Can’t you tell?” Riya pulled out and inspected one of the assault rifles.

Jock cleared his throat. “So with the guns, the grenades, and my delivery fee...”

She set down the gun and reached into a pocket. “Here. It all goes on the company card.”

“Company card, eh? Didn’t know the Department of Education was paying their teachers so well that—” Jock connected a card scanner to his phone, and before swiping, glanced at the black credit card with the golden scarab etching. He went instantly quiet. She watched him stare at the card, color draining from his cheeks, leaving him gray and sickly. Jock swallowed; his hands were shaking so hard it took him three tries to scan the card.

“S-sorry,” he stammered, thrusting the card back at Riya.

“What the hell’s up with you?” Riya asked, putting the card back into her pocket.

He shook his head, not meeting her eyes. “N-nothing. All good.”

“Jock? Have you seen the symbol on that card somewhere before?”

He closed his eyes and shook his head emphatically. “No. I haven’t… Seriously! Look, ma’am. I don’t know anything. I swear.”

“Ma’am? Really?”

“I got the payment. You got the guns. I’m gonna roll—”

He jerked backward to run into the plane, but Riya snatched his arm and pulled him violently back.

“Nope! You’re not going anywhere until you tell me what you know.”

“I don’t know anything, De Moor!”

“You recognize the symbol. The scarab beetle. Right?”

“Well. Sort of. I’ve never actually seen it before. Just heard the stories. You hear a lot of stories in my line of work. Meet a lotta shady people. A guy knows a guy knows a guy who saw something.”

“Jock, I don’t even know what that symbol means. I mean, I know there’s some group that pays for what I’m doing, but I don’t know anything about them.”

“Really? So you’re not…one of them?”

“One of who?”

“The…the people in the shadows. The people that, throughout history, have—you know—pulled the strings. Started the wars. Ended the wars. Covered it all up.”

Riya rolled her eyes. “Seriously? You see a gold scarab on a credit card and jump to Illuminati-level conspiracy BS?”

“All I know is, when weird shit goes down—I mean really, really weird shit—that symbol turns up. Shit gets covered up. People forget. People disappear. Whatever it is you think you’re doing with that bloody card, and those guns, and those new terrorist psychos setting up shop near here—yeah, I know about Iron Hymn or whatever they’re called—it ain’t gonna end well, doll. You’ve got yourself caught up in something that—”

The air surged with noise and light. Riya gasped and stumbled to the side, blasted by a shockwave of hot wind that rolled across the field. She stared, dumbstruck, at the source of the explosion. Above the forest to the north blossomed a miniature mushroom cloud of black smoke and golden flame encircled by threads of white lightning.

“Whoa, shit!” squeaked Jock. “What the hell was that?”

“Omicron,” panted Riya.

“Get this damn plane off the ground!” Jock shouted at his pilot. “I’m outta here, De Moor. I was never here! Tell your people, I don’t know anything. Not a damn thing!”

Riya stood beside the crates as the jet accelerated and tore into the sky. Her eyes were fixed over the top of the trees. The rolling smoke was rising against the blue, and even at this distance, Riya could hear its crackling, unnatural, electric roar. A smell of chemicals and putrid death reached her.

“It ain’t gonna end well,” she muttered to herself.

The handcuffs were chafing Riya’s wrists but she hardly noticed. She was enjoying herself. Besides the sharp-eyed interrogator, Egor, and two curious soldiers, there were now three additional officers and two mop-wielding inmate caretakers in Riya’s audience. They leaned against the walls and sat on the edge of the table.

“It was a magical explosion, wasn’t it?”

“Did the wizard die?”

“I love L109s!”

“Enough!” shouted the interrogator, hands on his head. “This isn’t story-time!”

Riya snickered. “You were the one that asked me how I ended up here.”

“Let her finish the story, sir!” whined Egor. “We want to hear about the storming of the terrorist compound!”

One of the inmates, staring intently over the top of his mop, said, “But the explosion… Didn’t the wizard destroy the terrorist’s hideout while you were buying the weapons from the Englishman?”

“Only half of—of—” Riya swallowed dryly. “Could someone get me a drink?”

“No, don’t get her a… Oh, why do I bother!” grumbled the interrogator as a soldier lifted a can of Coke to Riya’s lips.

“Much better,” said Riya. “So, when Omicron infiltrated the forest, he discovered that Iron Prayer’s compound consisted of two primary structures. The first and foremost, where they held the typhon, was a set of restored ruins; an impenetrable palace of concrete, barbed wire, armed turrets, and security cameras. However, the focus of his little private mission was on a second building in the forest. Situated in an abandoned hospital, Omicron discovered that the terrorists had a team of scientists working on a number of…unspeakable experiments.”

The Russian crowd leaned forward as one, eyes wide, breath held. Riya reveled in the wondrous power of having a classroom’s attention.

“It seems that having a monster to release wasn’t their only attack plan,” Riya explained dramatically. “They had been building something else. An army...of cyborgs.”

Whistles of appreciation followed this revelation.

“Omicron told me that they’d come close to perfecting the gadgetry: mechanical devices that plug straight into human flesh, connecting nerves and wires, muscles and machines. But he saved us the trouble from having to fight such a force. His magical explosion saw to that. The wizard leveled that facility, narrowly escaping with his life, and also brought back a souvenir.”

“A souvenir?” said Egor, a glint of understanding in his formerly dull eyes. “A gift, I think, for the Greek?”

Riya smiled. “Omicron got back to the village a little after I returned with the weapons. He was shaken up and drained of most of his power, but hellbent on going back into the woods the next day and finishing the job. We had to take out the main building and kill the typhon before the terrorists could use it in an attack. So we got some sleep, woke early, and marched off to battle.”

One day earlier…

Riya adjusted the scope on her newly purchased L96 sniper rifle. She lay on her stomach in dead leaves, hidden behind a tangle of thorns with Omicron. Through the trees, she studied the revamped ruins they would be attacking. A machine gun turret stood outside a pair of heavy iron doors. She could see eight terrorists patrolling outside the compound.

Leaving the sniper rifle on its stand, she turned and squinted through her binoculars at the snaking road that led out of the woods and up into the meadow beyond. Soft golden fog blanketed the morning landscape.

“I can’t see Achilles anymore,” said Riya, sitting up.

“No doubt he’s found somewhere to lay low until opportunity strikes. He’s like a new man today! Lucky I had the foresight to grab the device before blowing up the hospital.”

Riya stared at the wizard. His curls were tied into a messy bun on the back of his head. His mustache had bits of moss and leaf stuck in the white hairs. His mismatched eyes were bright and battle-ready.

“I need to ask you something, Omicron. The man who sold me these guns yesterday, he said he’s heard stories about our…our patrons. The quote-unquote company that pays for all this.”

Omicron slid his gauntlet onto his right hand and tightened the straps. “And?”

“And he was scared. He said those people—if they are people—have been behind all sorts of atrocities throughout history. Is that true?”

“Atrocities? Nay, nay, m’lady. I wouldn’t worry yourself about any of that. Rumors hover like flies over a corpse after groups like Evershine intercede in the affairs of humankind. Best not to heed them.”

“Evershine? Is that what the company’s called?”

“Apparently. They weren’t around back before I was sealed in the obovoid—I learned about the company when reaching out to old colleagues—but I’ve worked with similar groups in the past. They help people like us. They pay the bills. They keep the secrets. I’m happy to spend their cash, but as long as we have things under control, they need not play a larger role in our affairs.” Omicron looked up at her, his mouth a tight line. “‘Tis alright, m’lady. If you’re worried about your place in this war, about the moral stance of our struggle, don’t be. Rest assured, you are one of the good guys.”

“How can you be sure?”

“Because,” he said, sighing deeply, “I’ve been on both sides before. I had a bit of a…mid-lives crisis, once, long ago. I was tired of fighting for Order. Tired of the endless struggle, the futility of it all. And I switched over, for a time. I did things I am not proud of.”

“When was this? As Merlin?”

“Nay. Before that.”

Riya didn’t know what to say. This was the first time Omicron had spoken openly about his past. She didn’t want to jinx it.

Omicron flexed his fingers in the gauntlet. “Some answers in this world don’t come easy. But right now? It’s you and me and swift-footed Achilles against an army of radical terrorists with a monster that, given the chance, would literally eat your planet. Easy answer, m’lady.”

“We kick their arses?”

“Aye, we kick their arses.”

He nodded to the edge of the woods. “Here comes the first vehicle of the day. Let’s see if Achilles can pull off his little stunt.”

Riya inserted an orange earplug into each ear and lifted her binoculars. It took her a moment to locate the distant car tearing over the meadow toward them. She let out a low whistle. “I’ll be damned. Pretty sure that’s a Bugatti Chiron. Wow! You have any idea how much a car like that costs? More than my school’s budget for a year. But damn, if that isn’t a sexy car! But it’s gotta be going, what, eighty miles an hour? Can Achilles really…”

The luxury sports car ripped up a cloud of dust in its wake as it neared the woods. Then the car wasn’t alone. A man was running up behind the car, back hunched like a sprinter in the final second of a race. Through the binoculars, Riya could just make out Achilles’ wild, crooked smile, the sweat gleaming on his brow as he ran—practically flew—beside the car, and the sunlight glinting off the chrome plates of his new, mechanical, cyborg left shin and foot.

“Oh. My. Demigod,” gasped Riya, watching as Achilles came alongside the driver’s door, wrenched it open, and tugged out the driver. Riya saw the terrorist for only a moment as his body tumbled into the dust and was lost from view. Achilles leaped lightly into the speeding car and closed the door behind him.

“Er—Does he know how to drive?”

“Chariots, I suppose,” answered Omicron as the car swerved this way and that, engine sputtering. “‘Tis the same principle, I’d imagine.”

The car reached the woods. They could hear it banging along the path, though the trees hid it from view. Riya settled herself at the sniper rifle, focusing her gaze through the scope. Most of the terrorists by the front doors seemed oblivious, smoking and talking among themselves, but one man was staring down the road, standing very still. As Riya watched, the man’s eyes widened and he lurched to the gun turret. Before he could fire a shot at the speeding car, Riya’s rifle jerked on its stand, filling the air with the smell of gunpowder. She adjusted her scope in time to see the man slump forward over his gun. Two more terrorists marched onto the road, rifles raised. Riya pulled back the rifle’s bolt.

As both targets were neutralized by Riya’s sniping, the other terrorists scrambled, lifting their weapons as the car barreled toward the compound. At the last moment, Achilles jumped from the driver’s side door, skidding across the leaf-strewn ground on his heels as the speeding Chiron collided with the iron doors. The car exploded with a cloud of flame and raining steel, mangling the doors.

“Come on!” called out Omicron, leaping from their hiding spot and running toward the chaos. Riya left the sniper rifle on its stand and followed the wizard, cringing at the weight of the two SA80 assault rifles and the chain of grenades she draped over her shoulders.

As Omicron dashed down the slope in front of her, he readied his weapons. One of the Glock 17 pistols was holstered at his right hip. He had reluctantly accepted the gun from Riya, though she doubted he would use it. His beloved weapon of choice hung at his left hip, a coil of glinting steel attached to a two-handed hilt. He snatched the hilt with his right hand and drew it free. The steel uncoiled, revealing a deadly chain of connected blades that swung whiplike through the air, trailed in blue light from the magic gauntlet. As they ran, Omicron twisted the hilt in his hand and the blades snapped together as one, transforming the weapon into a glowing broadsword.

Riya flicked the safety catch of one of the SA80s. She hadn’t fired one of these since Iraq, and the weight and feel of it in her hands was instantly familiar, exciting and terrifying her in equal measure. The magical improvement to her back, too, was striking. Her spine ached with each step and her progress wasn’t as fast as before her injury, but it was thrilling to be running again at all.

They raced between the final trees and approached the compound. Riya lifted her rifle to fire at a terrorist by the doors, but Achilles got the man first, spinning on the ground like a hurricane and driving the chrome toes of his cyborg foot into the man’s head: an instant kill.

“Use the bloody pistol!” Riya shouted to Achilles, who, like Omicron, wore a Glock 17 on his hip.

Achilles ignored her, spinning to kick a flaming tire at a man approaching the gun turret.

Atop the high walls, men shouted and boots hurried in all directions. Riya, Omicron, and Achilles needed to get inside, fast. The explosion had twisted the heavy front doors, but they remained attached to their hinges and to one another.

“You gonna charm these things open?” Riya asked Omicron.

“Might not this be faster!”

Omicron stabbed his magical sword into the center of the doors, twisted, and broke them wide open. As they swung outward, Riya saw two terrorists within, snapping back the bolts on their AK-47s. Her finger flexed on the trigger. Her SA80 thundered. The men fell.

“Inward and onward, friends!” cheered Omicron, and they marched inside.

Riya wondered what these ruins had once been. A castle? A prison? The labyrinthine play-place of a young god? They moved through dim hallways of crumbling stone walls, past windows carved in unholy shapes—pentagrams, spades, an ankh on its head. Much of the structure was now hidden under the terrorist’s recent renovations. Concrete, cinder blocks, and rolls of barbed wire stood out against the ancient architecture, like shiny fillings among gray teeth. They moved deeper into the compound. Some of the rooms and halls were open to the sky, while others had high ceilings of cracked stone, spider webs, and security cameras. Around them rang the sounds of men shouting orders, guns being loaded, and boots pounding earth and stone, but they saw no one for the first minute inside.

“I’m getting tired of all these goddess-damned mazes,” grumbled Riya, staring down the sights of her rifle.

“This is nothing,” said Achilles. “You should see the mazes in the lands of Death, the paths to Elysium, Duat, Irkalla. You can wander for an age of the Earth and find no answers.”

“No thanks.” Riya adjusted the strap of the second SA80. “Say, either of you two gonna bother using this bloody heavy gun I got for you?”

“I will try out your firearm,” said Achilles.

Riya checked around the next corner, and feeling they were safe for the moment, lowered her weapon to hand the other rifle to Achilles. He weighed it in his hands doubtfully.

A hidden door, its surface painted like chipped stone, swung open to their left, colliding with Omicron. A terrorist leaped into the hall, a machine gun in his hands and a look of red fury in his eyes. Before Riya had a chance to fire at him, Achilles raised the SA80 like a club and swung it down into the terrorist’s collarbone. The man crumpled like a puppet with its strings cut.

Achilles handed the gun, barrel now bent, back to Riya.

“Good job,” said Riya dryly, dropping the broken rifle.

“Let’s go through here,” said Omicron, indicating the new doorway. “It will lead us toward the center of this heinous place. I can sense the typhon there. Can you, Achilles?”

Achilles ducked into the doorway with the wizard. Riya followed, adjusting the heavy grenades draped over her shoulder.

They moved down a sloped passage, mildewed and molded and smelling increasingly of decay. They turned a corner and headed lower still, past empty cells on either side that might have once held barrels of beer, or monks, or the bones of fallen heroes. Both Omicron and Achilles had gone tense, eyes wide and eager, feet silent as they crept forward.

Even Riya could sense it now—primordial evil, like an icy hand at her throat. No, a warm hand. A real hand! She tried to scream, but the hand covered her mouth and another snatched around her arms and torso, preventing her from using her gun. She kicked and tried to spin, but the assailant who had sneaked out from one of the dark cells and seized her was so large and muscular that her struggle came to naught. As she was pulled backward into the cell, she tried to hook her right foot against the wall, but her attacker was too strong.

She looked back into the hall. Wizard and warrior acted as one, drawing out their Glock 17s and firing. Riya gasped as her attacker hurtled backward. She turned to see the huge terrorist fall dead against the floor of the cell, both his eyes empty pockets of red.

“Well,” said Riya, shaking. “What a touching moment. Cheers, boys.”

Neither man had time to respond. Three more terrorists rushed toward them from the high end of the passage and another two came screaming from the low end. Riya leaped back into the cell, nearly tripping over the corpse inside. Reaching around the opening into the passage, she fired a deafening flurry of bullets. Two terrorists fell, firing their own rifles into the ceiling. Dust and pebbles rained.

Omicron dropped his pistol, rolled majestically across the floor, and twisted the hilt of his weapon, switching its function from sword to whip. The final three attackers raised their guns to fire as Omicron’s whip seared through their ranks. Three heads rolled and arcs of blood painted the edges of the hallway.

Then they heard it. A growl. A purr. A scraping of claw against metal.

“In here,” said Achilles, jogging to a door at the end of the passage.

Riya recoiled at the stench as the door was pulled open. She went through and emerged into a round and cavernous room. They were high up on a stone balcony. Steps to their right led down the circular wall. There appeared to be no terrorists here—not yet. Riya closed the door behind her, and Omicron managed to seal it shut with a strenuous bit of sorcery. They descended the stairs.

Medieval machines stood about the room, devices of rust and rotted wood, barely recognizable as the instruments of torture they once were. But the cubic cage was different. Shining chrome. Titanium fittings. Bars as thick as Achilles’ arms. It was made recently and for one purpose.

Riya lowered her gun and stepped forward.

The typhon had taken on the shape of its cage, stretched and swollen to fill every inch of space inside and bulge between the bars. It was so squashed and twisted that at first Riya had trouble seeing which body parts were which. There were limbs as broad as an elephant’s legs, flat toes with curved claws, a large section of back or belly protected by black plates like a hellish pangolin. Three eyes stared at them through the bars, from three different places. One was black, empty as a shark’s eyes. One was chrome. The last was blinking in Riya’s direction from a corner of the cage. As large as a dinner plate, this eye was distinctly human.

The grotesque shape shivered in the cage, groaned, exhaled rancid breath from between locked jaws.

Riya slid off the chain of grenades and held it in her hands. She had planned to pull a few pins and shove them into the monster’s mouth, but there was no room. The typhon couldn’t have opened its mouth if it wanted to.

“Well?” asked Omicron, glancing nervously toward the sealed door on the balcony.

“I dunno,” mumbled Riya, kneeling in front of the cage and trying not to lock gazes with any of the monster’s three eyes.

“They’re coming,” said Achilles. “I can hear them.”

The room reverberated with a blast of heat and rubble poured over them. Riya caught half a glance of the demolished doorway over their heads and armed men rushing onto the balcony, then Achilles grabbed her and whisked her around the far side of the cage. She struggled to load a fresh magazine into her SA80 as she squatted between Omicron and Achilles, their backs against the cold steel bars and warm stony plates of the caged typhon. A storm of bullets raged against the cage at their backs and the floor and walls in front of them.

“They’re hitting the typhon! They’re only going to make it stronger!” Riya screamed, but her words were lost in the tumult.

Blood dripped into Riya’s hair. She flinched and looked up. A jagged crack ran down one of the typhon’s plates, growing as more and more bullets pierced its flesh. Then the crack burst open, spraying a fine mist of blood and pus. Something raw and red reached up from the wound, branched, darkened. A newborn limb reached from the bars toward the ceiling, letting bullets tear at its exposed bone and muscle. Claws grew from the bullet holes and bits of plate appeared at its joints. In seconds, it was ten feet long and harshly muscled. Riya screamed as the limb swung down to one side, punched the ground, and sent the whole cage rocking onto its side.

Exposed to their attackers, Riya, Omicron, and Achilles took advantage of the immediate confusion and dashed to the farthest part of the room, where a heavy stone table stood against the curved wall. Achilles flipped the table onto its side with a swift chrome kick. Launching themselves behind it, they peered cautiously at the chaos all around. The typhon’s cage was leaning at an angle against the stairs, the new limb grasping desperately for a grip on the bars, searching for a way to escape.

“Oh bloody hell!” grunted Riya, patting down her body with her hands. Her grenades were gone. “What now?”

“Give me your sword,” Achilles demanded of Omicron, and when the wizard hesitated, Achilles wrenched it from his grasp and stood.

Riya screamed at him to get down. Guns roared. Achilles spun the blade in his skilled hands. Sparks flew from the steel, flinging bullets left and right. Achilles bent his legs—flesh and machine—and jumped. He shot off the ground and disappeared from her view. She heard him land on the balcony above, heard his guttural battle cry, the swishing of his sword, the gasps of the men he fought, the blast of their guns. A body thumped to the ground. Then a second. Then a third. When the fourth terrorist went silent, Riya chanced a peek over the fallen table.

Achilles stood upon the balcony, his broad back to her, panting. A thin stream of red ran down the length of Omicron’s sword and dripped to the ground. He leaped lightly from the balcony and landed beside the typhon’s cage. The monster continued to reach with its ghastly new arm, but all three of its eyes were fixed on Achilles.

A slow clap sounded from the balcony door. Riya and Omicron stood and watched as a man walked onto the balcony. Just another terrorist? Or something else? The man wore a suit, strangely bulky around the chest, and his hair and beard were dusty and disheveled. Bits of gravel stuck into his right cheek, his hair, his clapping hands.

“Isn’t that the guy you threw out of the Bugatti?” Riya asked Achilles, then she noticed that the terrorist’s right hand was clasped into a fist, holding something.

“Well, well,” said the bearded man in accented English. “I see you’ve met my little pet. Beautiful, isn’t she? The size of a dog when my men found her wandering the woods, but by the time we had gotten her into the cage, she had grown to this. And taken out twenty of my men. Good deaths, each of them. Very good deaths.”
