Omicron rolled his eyes. “Right, right. We get it. Neglected son of an oil tycoon turned death cult leader with a thing for bloodshed. As you can see, we’re busy finding a way to destroy this pet of yours. Please keep the monologuing to a minimum.”

“Destroy her? I think not, old man. You blew up my hospital yesterday. A shame, that. But today you will not succeed. You will not walk out of these ruins alive. None of us will.”

He undid the buttons of his jacket with his left hand. The jacket fell open to reveal a camo vest lined with blocks of C-4 and complex wiring.

“He’s got a suicide vest!” called Riya. “And a dead man’s switch.”

“So?” said Achilles.

“So if we kill him, he blows up like a barrel of Greek fire.”

The man on the balcony smiled. “We were going to release the beast in New York City. Can you imagine the scene? This beauty gobbling up all those fat, infidel tourists! Then come the policemen’s bullets, the army’s missiles. And my pet grows, and grows, and grows. How long, do you think, before nuclear options would have come into play? How long before the grand plans of Demir Dua would have wrecked the world? Ah, well. You have changed the plan now. It won’t have the same shocking beginning, but the end will be the same. My bomb sends me to paradise, all of you to hell, and blasts apart that cage. My pet feasts on our broken bodies, rampages across the countryside. Ankara, then Istanbul, Budapest, Vienna, Berlin. Who knows?”

Riya formulated her plan while he rambled. “Say, Achilles,” she said under her breath, “how about giving that sword back to Omicron. I think it will be the key to getting us out of here. After you do that, just…hop to it. Swift kick in the backside. Swifter the better.”

Achilles turned to Riya, confusion plain on his scarred face.

Riya nodded subtly at the balcony. “He wants to go out in a blaze of glory. Help him do so.”

Achilles grinned.

“The Iron Prayer will be answered!” the terrorist proclaimed, eyes closed, hands upheld. “The Iron Armageddon shall begin. All shall end! All shall drown in tides of blood and—”

Achilles tossed the sword to Omicron, who caught it by the hilt and twisted. The ghostly whip swung back and cracked forward, hooking onto the bars of the typhon’s cage. As Omicron yanked on the whip and the metal split apart, Achilles crouched and leaped. Landing beside the preaching terrorist, he spun around and brought his chrome foot into the man’s back. The terrorist fell with a sharp intake of breath. The cage burst apart and the typhon pounced upward, unfolding in an instant, stretching limb and claw. Riya watched its hideous form take shape. No tail, but huge plates of green and black over a humped back. Long arms and legs like a lizard’s, and the extra arm extending from one shoulder like a sentient tumor. Its head was like a tyrannosaur, barbed with horns and bristled with black feathers. It had an eye on its back, an eye on its chest, and the human eye centered over its jaws.

The terrorist fell into its open mouth. The monster swallowed him whole—an appetizer—then turned its full, terrible attention to Achilles. Achilles did not bother fighting, but stood with arms crossed as the monster stretched its neck for the kill.

The explosion was muted by the typhon’s flesh, but its force shook the room. Blood fountained from between the plates at the monster’s neck. Swirls of black smoke escaped through its mouth and nostrils. The eyes bulged. The typhon’s roar was strangled into a last squeal of helplessness.

At its final moment, the monster swelled and grew, sprouting cancerous fingers, feathers, a fourth grotesque eye, this one on its blood-soaked belly. Pale blue limbs sprouted like fungus in timelapse, reaching, grasping, blackening, curling, dying. The eyes burned out, one by one. Bloody plates tore free and clattered to the stone. The typhon hunched, quivered, and toppled forward, shaking the foundations of the ruins as its hideous corpse fell dead.

Riya wiped typhon blood off her face with the back of a sleeve. “Gross.”

“Went out in a blaze of gory, more like,” said Omicron, chuckling and switching his weapon back to its sword mode.

Achilles pointed to the blade in Omicron’s grasp. “Thank you for letting me borrow that. I like the sting of this skorpios.”

“Hm. Not a bad name for the weapon,” mused Omicron, holding up the bloodied sword.

“Can we please get out of here now?” asked Riya.

And they ran up the steps, through the dim halls, back into the maze of ruins and out the mangled doors.

“Truck! Truck!” shouted Riya, pointing to a massive military vehicle parked by the woods.

Terrorists returning to the compound from the woods shouted at them, fired AK-47s, rushed to find vehicles to make pursuit. Riya climbed into the truck’s cabin, found the keys above the driver’s side mirror, and waited as Omicron and Achilles joined her in the front seat. She glanced at the wing mirror just in time to see a terrorist raise his gun. His bullet shattered the mirror. Riya stabbed the key into the ignition, gave it a hearty turn, and pounded her foot onto the accelerator.

“And we drove through the day, first with Iron Prayer on our heels, then later pursued by the Turkish military. Not very fun. We finally reached the northern coast at dusk. Found a boat. Stole the boat. Set off across the Black Sea. That was… A journey across water can be a powerful thing, you know. The waves. The wind. And at last, distant lights on the Russian coast. A trip like that is somehow both epic and personal. The Greeks had a word for it: nostos. Anyway, I guess we must have crashed into the beach just before dawn and I was knocked unconscious. I don’t remember. You all must have gotten to me before Omicron and Achilles, and they had to escape while they could. All I know is, I woke up with a killer headache, handcuffed to a hospital bed in this prison.

“That’s the story. You asked. I answered.”

The interrogation room had been cold before she started her story, but the heat from all the bodies packed inside made Riya sweat. Soldiers, officers, clerks, caretakers, and even a handful of inmates sat and stood around the woman handcuffed to the chair. The interrogator himself had left the room some minutes before, overwhelmed.

“Wow,” mumbled one soldier. “What a story.”

“But is not true, right?” asked another in broken English. “All those bullets flying, missing heroes. All that lucky timing!”

“Well, of course there’s going to be embellishments!” countered a young officer. “The lady is a master storyteller.”

“Or perhaps,” put in Riya, “we fought with the goodwill of a goddess, whose blessings lent us divine luck for the day.”

They turned to arguing among themselves in Russian about this interpretation of events.

“Anyone have the time?” asked Riya.

“Almost two in the afternoon,” a clerk told her.

Riya nodded. “All right then. Here’s what’s going to happen next. Any minute now, the lights in this prison will suddenly go out. You’ll start to hear noises in the halls. Breaking glass. Gunshots. Shouting. Probably an explosion or two as the computer system is obliterated to erase any recording of my confession. Then they will come through that door to rescue me. And it won’t just be Omicron and Achilles. Sable Crow will be here, too. Helluva woman, Sable Crow. Now, you could fight back, if you really wanted to, but I think we both know who’s going to win the day. One way or another, I will soon be out of here, enjoying a birthday dinner with my comrades. So, anyone care to hasten the inevitable and undo these handcuffs?”

The sea of faces looked at her, some amused, some doubtful, some frightened.

“The, uh…” mumbled Egor, “…the resurrection squad is coming here? For real?”

Riya shrugged, though none of her audience saw the gesture, as just then, the lights went out.
